The Archive hummed at it as if reminding a child how to sit. A woman ran her hands along a drawer labeled Frost–Unmarried and drew out a ribbon of something white that was not cloth and not light; when she put it to the stone, the stone pretended to be morning in a month it had not meant to see. For a moment it was too much like theater and Liora felt her temper climb as if it had been invited to perform; then the stone sighed in that way of old things finding a position they can maintain without resentment, and the frost settled into a filigree that looked like the veining on certain sweet loaves. Corin crouched, put his knuckle to it, and came up with a touch of ice that did not bite but did not flatter either. “Once you’ve done it, you can do it again,” he said, half warning and half benediction. “That is the problem and the gift.”

They all felt it when the Archive looked at the Fell-Flats as a child looks at the cakes laid out of reach on a high shelf. It wanted to show off. Vesper’s jaw moved, the small muscle that lives along the ear speaking to the parts of the body that do not listen otherwise, and she did not permit it. Liora did not applaud because withholding applause is sometimes the only respect worth offering. She allowed herself the mean little glee of observing Vesper behave like a governor rather than a virtuoso, and hated the glee because it did no one any good.

Disappointment, like mildew, has to be looked for or it finds you first. In the camp at the far edge where the banners loved color more than they loved anything with bones, a group had taken to calling themselves the Lusters, because there are always people ready to make a club out of their weather. They had been saving their stares for the count’s last breath and had been cheated of a tidy apocalypse, and now they were inclined to push the new work until something broke with a satisfying sound. Elyse came back from fetching water with her braids disordered and her expression cleaner than usual by virtue of irritation. “They are clever in the old way,” she reported, a verdict she did not hand out lightly. “They’ve got a girl who can make light sulk and they’ve told her everyone will be grateful when she finally makes an honest mess. If we don’t keep an eye on them they’ll break the tuner and then write poems about it.”

Kite went to sit in their path with his boat on his lap and the air of a man who would be delighted to be told to move and equally delighted to refuse. Shade took up a position near the rope because men who like to untie knots can be relied upon to recognize people tying them for sport. Tern found the bell-woman’s smaller bell and stood with it like a man who could ring if told without having to be asked twice. Liora went the other way because Tamsin had written in smaller script, do not stand always where you are needed or they will mistake you for furniture. She went to the place where the Night-Tears had put up their second leaves and she whispered to them about patience and then laughed at herself for the kind of person who whispers to bells in seed-form.

It was Corin who found the writing under the Spire. He cared for vents and seams the way some men care for the backs of children’s knees, and when Vesper’s people needed someone to go into a slot cut by the old ones with very little regard for human ribs, he was the one who would fit and whose pride would not take offense. He came back hours later with dust in his hair and his wrist scratched where a tool had forgotten its manners, and a look in his eye that Liora had last seen when he had found an old line of mortared stone where a garden shed had claimed to be the eldest thing on a property. “They left jokes,” he said, dazed and delighted. “Scratched in where no one could see them unless they were being insulted by the fit of the place. This one”—and he drew with his finger in the air—“is a little note that says do not stand under this unless you are better than a god at guessing. This one says my sister married an idea and they never had children. This one is a sketch of a pigeon relieving itself on the head of a man wearing a crown and the crown is shaped exactly like this.” He pointed to the lip of the column where it forgot itself and Liora felt the human of the old builders reach up like a weed and take her by the ankle and insist that she remember all grand rooms are built by people who made faces while they worked.

By afternoon the Lusters had tried to make a spectacle and had been given soup instead. Kite had told them a story about the time he and Shade had rowed a mile backwards by mistake because the river had been insulted and then had to pretend they had intended it, and somehow in the telling the urge to break the tuner curdled into a cranky desire to be admired for not breaking it. Elyse passed around a batch of curses she had written in a neat hand and told them they could keep them for domestic use if they promised to insult only tea, not systems. Tern rang the little bell when any sentence grew so elegant it forgot about sense. Liora wrote a line in the dust that said we will not lift what we cannot set down without apology and left it there until someone’s foot removed it because feet are the honest grooms of pride.

Vesper came to Liora not because she wanted to but because leaders speak to the person who has arranged to be an obstacle without being rude. She sat this time as she had before, on the outer rim of Liora’s circle of ordinary, and her eyes did that glitter that belongs to people who have overachieved in their disdain for themselves and are trying to decide whether a compliment might help. “I wanted it,” she said without preface, because the day had knocked pleasantry out of her mouth. “I wanted a clean end, a good story, a beautiful last note, and I have been given this instead, which is work, and scheduling, and the particular fatigue of knowing the better thing will be to get up tomorrow and get up again after that. You can make fun of me now if you like. I deserve it, though I warn you I may enjoy it.”

Liora considered the delights of unkindness and let most of them go because she was, alas, improving with practice. “I will save it for an hour when I am tired and you are arrogant,” she said, which earned her a proper smile and the raising of a shoulder that suggested Vesper had wanted to be forgiven and was angry to find that forgiveness had no glamour. “Tell me why you hate doves,” she added, because small questions won where all the large ones make enemies, and Vesper blinked and then, absurdly, told her.

Her father had bred them as a hobby, it seemed, and had given them all names that could be whistled and then had forgotten them and whistled names at random. Half the birds had starved because they were waiting to be called to supper by a song their throats did not recognize, and Vesper had taken that into her bones as one takes into one’s throat a slice of an orange eaten at the exact wrong hour. “I dislike creatures that require a performance to eat,” she said, harsh and precise with the old grievance, and Liora recognized the ragged place where a childhood sometimes puts its teeth and felt distaste at her own complicity in admiring Vesper’s wound. “I will not be a dove,” Vesper said, low, and then the mountain gave a little shrug like a man settling his jacket and the Archive rustled its drawers as if to say there are worse things to be than named and fed.

The hawk, having failed to properly land on Corin’s head earlier, found a new way to insist on its presence: it spoke from the side of a rock where any other bird would have chosen to be quiet. “You will be late to everything you love if you make yourself stay here,” it told Liora with the shamelessness of a creature that has never kept a ledger. “You will be early to your own death if you go everywhere anyone asks you to go. Choose the rudeness you prefer.” Elyse threw her a look that said do not dignify a hawk, and Liora laughed because the advice was useful and because she was becoming more and more the sort of person who used laughter to keep from setting anything on fire.

Late, at the hour when even children who are fascinated by the idea of standing awake under a painted pigeon become heavy as bread in arms, the rope’s song changed and then corrected itself, and six people looked up at once with the same expression: the old one, the witcher, two masons, Liora, and Vesper. It was not an alarm; it was an inclusion. The rope had learned a second part to the tuner’s line and was suggesting a harmony. Vesper looked almost frightened, which is an interesting expression on a face that prefers to be the person frightening others. “It will do this now,” she said, quietly to herself and not quietly enough that Liora did not hear. “The work will go on where it is not pointed. The rooms will learn to talk to one another when I am not in the room. How unbearable, to have made something willing to proceed without my applause.”

“How bearable,” Liora said, thinking of Tamsin in her room with soft lamps and the meticulous comfort of put-away spoons, and thinking of men with oars who measured the world by their arms and did not try to tell the river what it was, and thinking of Bramble, who had at last found the exact place between Elyse and Corin where his heat kept both their ankles warm and had fallen into sleep as sincere as any vow. “To know you are no longer the hinge. To be something useful like a shelf instead.” Vesper made a terrible face and then agreed with the part of herself that had learned, at last, that the better insult is the one you keep.

That night the Night-Tears opened their mouths and did not ring because they had learned taste in their hours closed. They showed their pale throats to the green—no longer the insistence of a plan but the lament of a habit—and then filled with dew and held it like pearls. Liora touched one with the back of her finger and thought of Tamsin’s letter and wrote one back, not with reed and trout but with the ordinary vigor of a pen on paper and the knowledge that rivers would not mind being denied a small errand. She said that she had stood at the place where endings are supposed to occur and had been offered instead the very long work of mending a world that had been taught to think it could be better after it broke, and that she had said yes to the mending because there are only two kinds of people in such stories and she had decided to be the kind named afterward for braids or for sensible shoes rather than for plummets or for glory. She wrote that she would come home as long as she could, as often as she could, as soon as she felt she had left a mark anyone could find their way by in her absence, and that she had invented another word and it was not heroish; it was worksome. She thought her mother might forgive this.

In the hours before dawn, when the mountain tells itself the fables it keeps for grandchildren, something padded past their circle that made Bramble sit up without barking. He lifted his head, sniffed, considered whether to make a fuss, and then, decisively, thumped his tail twice. Liora knew better than to ask him to translate; he had been bred for presence, not for exegesis. In the gray that followed, a woman came into view with a stick in her hand and a baby strapped to her chest and half a loaf under her arm. She had the soft-ankled stride of those who do not know they are being watched by history. “We came up for the end,” she said to no one as if apologizing to a fence. “We will stay for the middle. Does anyone need a stitch put in a sleeve.” She sat without being asked and threaded her needle with floss that had been dyed with onion skins, and Liora found herself stupidly grateful in the way you are when a world has not ended and someone offers to fix shirt cuffs.

When the sun decided to report for duty, the Fell-Flats sent a message by smoke. It did not say gratitude; it said we had frost and did not, and the second part of the sentence had been written by a twelve-year-old with a reckless love for grammar. Vesper saw it and did not pretend indifference, and she did not betray herself by speaking more than the room required. Liora saw her take the news into that place where she carried the story of the doves and the underfed; she saw her rearrange her contempt into usefulness. She stood and stretched and glanced toward the blue room with all the old hunger in her face and then glanced toward the white shelf with a new attention that would not let the sugar-likers stand without a bell. “Come be my argument,” she said to Liora, dry as a piece of toast that would still be the best thing you ate all day. “We will open another room. We will close two. We will tell the rope it is not a choir unless it receives a medal from the bell-woman. We will make a policy about pigeons. We will write it down. We will be contemptibly alive.”

“Worksome,” Liora agreed, because she had found a word and meant to make it pull. She stood into the day with the willow singing a little because it had learned, like the rest of them, that there was more to be done than singing, and that songs might have to be used like tools and tools like prayers and prayers like bells rung not for endings but to get people to come and eat. The hawk’s shadow went by without comment. The rope held its line. The Archive adjusted its drawers hopefully and was told plainly to wait its turn. Bramble trotted ahead to ask the path what sort of foolishness it planned before breakfast, and the path, out of affection, tried to behave. They started for the door with the light planks and did not step on the places that liked to be looked at more than walked upon, and behind them the Night-Tears held their dew and decided to ring later for something that would need ringing more than any of this.

The reeds at Woodlake whisper when there is news. They knock their hollow bones against one another and make a music like chilled bells, or like nervous teeth, and the sound carries over water black as a sleeping mirror. Dragonflies rocked on the air, lantern-bright, and the first pale fogs of evening came unshouldered out of the water and the alder trees. Somewhere, deep beneath the surface, something boomed — not loudly, not at all like thunder; more a steady drumbeat in the bones, a reminder, a hello. It had been happening all week and nobody agreed what it meant. Perhaps the lake settling. Perhaps an old, fat catfish, thumping the silt with its tail. Or perhaps — the old women said, in the back galleries of the market — perhaps Woodlake itself had taken up a heartbeat to warn its princess.

Liora liked to walk when it began. Alone was not quite the word, because Bramble would not entertain it. He trotted beside her, ears up, tail feathering brief spells in the air, each step of his small paws loud with importance. He was a mutt who looked like the leftover dream after a braid had been unplaited — half grey like morning ash, half brown, with a nose that was always damp and always looking for secrets. His eyes were ridiculous. Not because they were large, though they were, but because they wore all their feeling on their glossy sleeves. It’s uncommon for princes to allow such honesty, and princesses risk it only if they are very brave or very foolish; Liora was sometimes both.

When the boom came tonight, Bramble stopped so suddenly he slid among oak leaves and flailed, and then he lifted one paw and pressed it against her boot as if to say, Could we maybe not. She bent and pressed her forehead to his, and he sneezed and looked aggrieved.

“It’s like a drum far away,” Liora said to him. “Or else it’s like when you lie with your ear against the earth, and you’re trying to hear someone crossing the heather. It’s something under all this.”

Bramble made a sound. The sound said this: I am a good dog. I am your dog. I will follow you under lakes and into fires. But perhaps first supper.

“You eat like a raven,” she said. “You’ve had three suppers.”

She wore no circlet tonight, no gem-knotted cloak. If anyone had seen her in the wilder reeds and asked they would have thought her a woodcutter’s daughter with wandering thoughts and mud on her hem. She had the look of her mother in the eyes — green as green can be without looking witch-lit — and her father’s mouth, a little severe when she was thinking hard. She carried a willow-twist staff because the kings and queens of Woodlake had always carried such, partly for ceremony and partly because the willow leaned and listened and had opinions about the way magic moved. It swore it could hear the sky sometimes. It hissed when she dipped the end into dark water. Hush, hush, hush.

“They’re getting louder,” she said.

Another boom, a slow pulse. Her heart tried to match it; it made her chest feel asymmetrical. She touched the staff to the surface and for an instant it wasn’t a mirror anymore. She saw blue stone and two figures in a long room with a ceiling of glass — or not glass, a substance so polished it had forgotten how to be touched — and behind those figures a column of light that wasn’t light, and the feeling of falling and falling. She gasped and drew back. The water returned to the lake’s ordinary interiors: weed, silt, those tiny curling creatures that looked like punctuation marks.

Bramble sneezed again, harder, and then he trotted forward and pressed his paws onto the wet wooden deck and peered into the lake as if he might find the very thing, and if he could catch it maybe he would shake it until it let go of their world. His reflection distorted. He growled at himself, then pranced and forgot why.

“Come on,” Liora said. “It’s almost bell-five. If I don’t sit to supper and smile and tell three stories to the minor houses, I will hear about it from now until the thaw.”

She went up the path without watching for where she placed her feet, trusting the path to be where it always was. And it was. The castle of Woodlake lifted in gentle habits above her, not a beast of stone so much as one that had grown. It was built of pale marble and dark timbers, and there were gardens that went in and out of its bones. The windows were tall and full of light until the day failed, and then they held on to the light and made it seem like their own. The walls had feathers of moss and the roofs drank the first snow. It was a place that had never been at war, not that anyone living could recall; Woodlake had sent boats loaded with grain, had sent woodworkers to shore up cities after quakes, had sent a princess with white flowers in her hair to marry a prince and stitch one wound shut. They had never kept an army ready. Perhaps that was an old omission at last ready to be corrected. Liora did not think of that as she climbed. She thought of the reverberating beat beneath the dock, and of how far off the warm smell of spiced lamb was.

Three boys were racing at the gate. They stopped when the guards nodded and Liora lifted a hand and said, “Who’s winning?” One boy with a tear on his cheek. One with a scab on his forehead. One with a piece of twine around his wrist, as if a string could keep him from falling away.

“Me,” the three said together.

“Then you’ll have to race again,” Liora said gravely. “We can’t have three winners. What would the drummer say? He’d have to beat a very odd rhythm to march you home.”

They blinked at her. The smallest said, “Princess, is the drum in the lake bad?”

“Only if you’re a fish who loves silence.” She pushed at the smallest boy’s shoulder, hardly at all, and he laughed, relieved, and then they were off, feet slapping.

In the entry hall the new banners hung with the old. The new ones smelled faintly of dye and river-wet linen. The old ones smelled of dust and thyme and grandmothers. Liora touched one as she passed. The woodcutters’ guild had adopted a stag rampant this year. Last year they’d made-do with crossed saws. “A promotion,” she murmured.

“Who, my dear?” Queen Tamsin looked up from where she sat on the bottom step of the stairs correcting a ledger even though she had a perfectly good steward to do it. Other queens use their hands to wave or to hold hands out for kissing. Tamsin used hers to count. Liora loved her more than she knew how to say and also found her sometimes like an irritating splinter she couldn’t quite pull free.

“The stag,” Liora said. “It used to be saws. Now I suppose it’s a more rugged identity. The lake is booming again.”

“That it is,” Tamsin said, pursing her mouth. “We’ve sent three boats out. Corin says there’s nothing out of the ordinary going on under the teasel islands.”

“Tell Corin to bring the boats back before full dark.”

“You think there’s danger?”

“I think there are secrets. You know how Bramble gets when there are secrets.”

They both looked down. Bramble had found the steward and was making a complex attempt to steal the man’s pencil by appearing to be concerned about the state of his boots. The steward laughed significantly, and then he gave in and tickled Bramble behind one ear. Bramble’s eyes rolled back. He made an incoherent sound, the sound of absolute surrender to the idea of being a dog.

When supper began, the hall expanded to accommodate it. It always did. The rafters seemed taller. The air grew rich with steam and spice and the holler of everyone trying to talk low. Liora took her place and answered every question with patience and a soft voice. She asked more in return. This was something Tamsin had impressed upon her early: if you want people to trust you, you must be curious about them. It is easier to lie to someone who never asks, or to someone who hides inside their own head with a nice book and a dog. Much easier.

“…and the early apples will be thin,” said the boy with the twine around his wrist, now carefully man-shaped and placed with his father at the low table near the dais, the one for the small houses.

“We’ll send trade to Fairmere,” Liora said. “They’ve had too much rain and their orchards will bend themselves down with what they can’t press. We can put it into jars: spiced, boiled, dried. You know the ginger recipe? It’ll turn your tongue into a river.”

“Princess,” his father said, bowing slightly, grateful and a bit embarrassed. “The drumming—”

“I know,” she said. “We’re watching.”

Tamsin’s eyes skimmed the hall. She had the way of knowing when to look where — her version of magic, Liora sometimes thought, stronger than any spell. Now her gaze paused, and a moment later the door-hall opened of its own accord because a man, a messenger, had made up his mind that it would. He looked as if three roads had each tried to keep him. Dust at the cuffs and the mouth. Rain in his hair like needles. He wore the black coat of the Crown’s roadmen — those who bore news that had to be heard even when it wished otherwise — and he was exhausted in the peculiar way of those who don’t stop because stopping would be worse.

He did not kneel. He blinked when he saw Liora with her willow staff leaning at the table and Bramble under her chair; he blinked when he saw Tamsin on the stair. He took a breath that sounded like it hurt him and said, “I come out of Vale. I came as far as Woodlake in two days. I am sorry for my face. I have a letter. I have something to tell. There is a princess in the North, and she says she is going to end us.”

The hall steamed and went still. People exchanged glances the way fish exchange flashes of light. A princess, he had said, and not one of the old pricking pranks like put a frog in your boot. End us.

“Come closer,” Tamsin said.

Bramble rose, hackles up. He was not often a dog for hackles. Liora put a hand down and felt him vibrate under her fingers and he calmed because he believed in her hand more than he feared whatever this was.

“What is your name?” Liora asked as he climbed the dais steps. He kept his eyes off the food and she loved him a little for that.

“Saeth,” he said.

“You’ll sit and eat when you’ve told me.”

He nodded, once. He put the letter into Tamsin’s hand. It bore in cracked red wax the sunburst of the Upper Crown, but Tamsin didn’t break it. She watched Saeth’s mouth.

“She calls herself Vesper,” Saeth said. “Princess Vesper of the Black Spire, though the Spire belongs to no one. She went up three moons ago. She took two hundred and thirty-seven with her, and half were witchers and half were masons and the rest were… the rest were the sort of men who build roads through places where roads do not wish to be. And women. She took women too. She said she had a right to the Spire because her grandmother’s grandmother had watched the sky fall open there once. She keeps saying things like that. She says a great many things. At first everyone laughed. It’s not easy to take someone seriously when they bring bees into a meeting hall and light them like candles. But we stopped laughing when the auroras came. We stopped when the rivers ran backwards a while. We stopped when — forgive me the saying — when birds fell like apples. Then some came and told the Crown and the Crown told me to run faster.”

“What she wants,” Tamsin said. She kept the letter whole, as if breaking it might break something else.

“She says the planet is wrong. That Alderra was bent a little crooked and the crookedness is why the sky sometimes catches and tears, and why the mountains still strap themselves on each other when we sleep. She says to fix it would be to end it. She says to end it would be to begin it right. She says she would lay her head down in the ash along with us and sleep fine.”

Liora felt ill. She sat with her hands open on her knees, the way you would if you were going to stand suddenly and did not wish to knock the table askew. The willow staff, propped behind her, hummed so faintly she could have believed she imagined it. People say mad to mean dangerous. They say dangerous to mean mad. Neither are useful for understanding. She had been taught by a woman who kept bees and who did not light them. She had been taught to look.

“What does she have?” Liora said. “What does she hold in her hands that makes her able to do more than promise?”

Saeth swallowed. “They brought machines up. Old ones. Things that had been in the Black Spire since before by-Grandmother time. Ropes that sang when you pulled, and glass that changed when you looked at it, and ladders that turned to light when you stood on them. I did not go inside. I sat on the scree behind a pike of stone and watched. The night was a green shade like bruising. She stands there with her hands up and the stars flicker, and the air goes thin. She… Princess, forgive me, I know how it sounds, but the ground rose and bit itself. The Black Spire is not so black anymore. It’s shining. And there’s a humming, and the rivers—” He reached for the letter in Tamsin’s hand as if it were a little boat that might steady him. “When I came into the new road through the Ash Plain, I had to tie rocks to my boots to keep from taking two strides and then being thrown ten in the air as if by laughter. Everyone is frightened. Some are in love with it.”

“Who is she kin to?” Tamsin said, and broke the seal after all. Her eyes moved. Her mouth made a tight line.

“Some say she’s of the Vale line, but she doesn’t claim them. She claims everything older. She says she is daughter to the first night. She speaks in that way that moves people. I could feel it under my tongue even across the stones. She says we have been sleeping in the wrong bed.”

Bramble, who had crept up, put his chin on Liora’s knee and shook once, as if he’d just come out of cold water. She scratched his head and felt him begin to melt again. “I know that way of speaking,” she said. “They pull you toward an edge and then tell you you’ve always lived there and your bones knew it before you did.”

“Princess,” Saeth said, startling. “She asked for you. For you by name. For Liora of Woodlake.”

The air changed at the table. Not colder. Tighter. Bramble made a low sound, a bottle too much corked.

“What did she say?”

“She said: Tell Liora of Woodlake to put her ear to the water, and she will hear what I hear, and she will see that the planet wants an ending.”

Tamsin’s hand came down on Liora’s shoulder, warm. She squeezed. “Eat,” she told Saeth, brisker than the moment deserved. That was her way of holding things together. “Then sleep in the old winterroom. We’ll decide in the morning what to send back.”

After, when everyone else had eaten their sighs and gone to their rooms, Liora stood in the Map Room with the maps in the dark. She did not light a flame. Sometimes you see more in the dark, because the dark is an honesty that doesn’t like to be interrupted. The maps had been drawn over a hundred and thirty-four years by a woman with a particular manner of observation. Every tree that had mattered to that woman was caught in the neat wrist of her ink. Every river that had changed its mind. The Black Spire was there, a small thorn in the north, with a note in tight hand: Do not go.

“I’m going,” Liora said to no one. To the ink, perhaps.

Her own breath came out and made her a small cloud to stand in. She put her finger to the Spire and imagined it shining. She imagined Vesper with her hands up, calling out the names of the old things — whether the names were true or were just noise that could be coaxed into shape by the quality of her wanting. Liora did not want to speak with her. She wanted to return the lake to silence and to tell the children at the gate that if they cried for their mothers it would be only because they’d both run too hard and had a stitch.

“Do you ever feel that there’s something in your head that is not you?” Liora asked in the dark.

The room did not answer. The willow leaned against the wall.

Bramble exhaled his little snore, and the sound made the lack of answer less bothered. He turned on his back and presented the ceiling with his stomach, with all his vulnerability, because he had decided the ceiling wasn’t interested in doing him harm. Liora knelt and put her hand to that warm small belly. She let herself rest like that until her thoughts had slowed.

She did not always dream; she was one of those frustrating people who sleep like a healthy river does: with clarity. But she dreamed that night. In the dream she was standing on the dock with the fog coming up in threads, and her staff was gone, and the lake took a breath beneath her feet and said her name. Not in words — in shape and in pull. She knelt and put her ear to the water and the surface tension held her. It felt like being a cup set out on a table when someone is stomping down the hall. The drumming was louder. It became a steady beat that belonged to a heart that was too slow for any body that size, except there are bodies larger than we are used to saying aloud. It spoke the way hearts speak: not in the language of promises, but in the language of forever. She thought: It wants to be different. She thought: Maybe it wants to hold a different sky.

She sat up in the dream and there was a woman beside her. The woman’s hair had the color of limestone that has been underwater a thousand years. She was smiling as if she had never learned how not to. She was not beautiful. She was the kind of person you would look at twice because she didn’t look like you expected an ending to look.

“You’ve been putting your ear to it,” the woman said. Her voice carried the North in it. There is a cadence you get when you speak with the wind rattling at your mouth. “That’s good. The ears are the last to lie. Sometimes the eyes lie because the eyes are hungry. But the ears are like wheat. They listen and they lean.”

“Who are you?” Liora said, even though she knew.

“Princess Vesper,” the woman said, and dipped her head as if to be polite and to mock courtesy in exactly the same gesture. “I’ve been trying to reach you. Sorry to come into your dark like this. It’s too late to be careful. I suppose I could have sent a dove. I don’t like doves.”

“You’ve been calling rivers backwards,” Liora said. That wasn’t what she had meant to say. The dream had made her mouth peculiar. “You’ve been making birds fall.”

“Some things fall because they’re tired,” Vesper said. “Some because a different wind owns them. I’m showing the planet its choices. It’s been doing the same thing so long it hasn’t the imagination.”

“Choice,” Liora said. “You mean disaster.”

“I mean correction,” Vesper said, gentle as milk. “You know the stories. How many times the sky has wintered badly. How many times it cracked. How many times the mountains shook hands so hard it broke the houses between. We keep patching Alderra like a kettle. She’s nowhere near the shape she began with. I think we might as well admit it. We could all sit close when it happens. We could hold children tight and not pretend to ourselves. After, perhaps we go somewhere better. Perhaps there is a rightness. Or perhaps there is nothing and we wear that nothing like velvet. It hardly seems worse than this.”

“I know despair when I hear it,” Liora said. “I also know a woman who loves a stage. Who loves the breath before the song when everyone is waiting for the next note to fall down their backs.”

Vesper’s smile twitched. “You think I like the theater of it.”

“You brought bees into a meeting hall,” Liora said. “A little theatrical.”

Vesper shrugged. She had the shape of someone who had never been told no enough to dislike it. Liora flinched with an old memory: being a small girl and watching another small girl smash a dragonfly between stones just to see if the light went out of it. “I don’t want to fight you,” Vesper said. “You do not strike me as particularly gifted at it, and I hate being bored. Why not lay down your willow and climb the Spire? See what I see. If I am wrong, we will both come down and do what you like. If I am right, I will take your hand and we will pull the planet out of its old bed and lay it in a new one.”

There were a dozen questions that a careful person would ask then. Liora asked none of them. She stood up in the dream. Her knees were stiff even though dream-knees don’t have to be. “No,” she said.

“Princess,” Vesper said, and her head tilted a little, and for an instant the whole world seemed to sway toward her like trees that have just been rooted up. The power was in her throat and in the cadence, but it was also in her hips and her quiet feet. Everything about her declared a different gravity. “Do not be foolish. You are brave, yes. You are good. Goodness is for farmhouses. We are standing in the place where large choices are made. Sometimes goodness must be set down. The people do not need you to be kind. They need you to be what the air is, and what the old stone is. You must be the hand that does not shake.”

Liora could not breathe for a moment. She knew with a child’s clarity that if she listened to that music too long she would begin to clap along. So she thought of Bramble’s snore, and of the way the steward laughed, and of the taste of the first apple slice of autumn, and of her mother’s ledger written in that narrow unsentimental hand, and of the boys at the gate tying string to their wrists to keep from falling up. It steadied her. “No,” she said again. “You are throwing rocks at a beehive because you like the sound, and you do not care if the honey is ruined.”

Vesper’s hand moved. The dock under Liora’s feet tilted. The dream was no longer a dream; it became one of the other things. A presentiment or a test. Liora felt water come up and walk into her mouth. It filled her ears. It crowded her eyes. She opened them and Vesper was standing over her with something like tenderness. “You will come anyhow,” Vesper said. “You will come and say no, and that will be good too. I prefer to have an opposer. We make meaning when we stand opposite. Without you I am only a girl on a rock pulling at the dark.”

“I am not your meaning,” Liora said, but it was full of water, it was an ugly little bubble of remark, and Vesper laughed like someone who had owned laughter since she was born.

Liora woke in the Map Room with her cheek stuck to the cold table. Bramble was standing on her stomach, which is not forgiving if you are a princess. His paws dug into her softest parts and his nose pushed her chin as if to say: up. up. Up now. He smelled worried, which is a little like hot bread and a little like wet. Outside, the lake boomed. Not a dream. She sat and scrubbed her face. The taste of salt and oak smoke sat at the back of her throat.

“I will go,” she told Bramble. The word tasted like iron. “Not to say yes. To say it where she can hear me. Not to let this planet be broken by a woman who enjoys her own voice too much. We’ll leave after the market. Tell no one.”

Bramble wagged once and then had to wag again because the first wag had not been enough. He ran in a small circle because his joy was too big to fit inside him. He brought his rope. Then he forgot the rope and barked at his rope as if it had been impudent.

The morning came up indifferent to their plans, perhaps on purpose. The sky had the color of a metal that has been in many mouths and has come out of all of them disagreeably. People were in the lanes early for Bloomtide — the year’s first market where the city’s winter-secret crafts come out and the winter-hidden people do too. Liora ate a piece of bread while walking and someone put a smear of honey on it at the last moment and she licked her thumb. The woodsmoke had a hopeful smell. Everything was precious and ordinary.

“Princess, the herbman says his rosemary died again and he swears it’s not his fault despite the new sign on his window that says BEWARE OWLS.”

“Perhaps the owls are his scapegoats,” Liora said. “Tell him to grow thyme for a change.”

“Princess, the western stair has a crack.”

“Does it grow?” she asked. “Is it a crack that has ambition? Or does it look back at you with sleepy eyes and say, enough, I am done.”

“Princess, the lake boomed during the candle-blessing. Do you think the candles are now gods.”

“I think the candles will still go out,” she said, and smiled, and did not look aside toward the water because if she did she might not stop.

At Market, she bought nothing and everything. A boy put a living beetle made of glass into her palm and it ticked and then it slept. A woman pressed a ring on her finger and said for no money at all, take it, I cannot bear to have it in my house. The ring had a small flaw you could love if you looked and looked and looked. And she took a packet of seeds labeled Night-Tears and pretended she had not seen the little sketch in the margin of a plant blooming in the shape of a bell with its mouth shut. She took them because she wrote the names down and the names became her friends. Night-Tears. She wanted to know what they would do if you gave them rain.

When the water rose in a shape that was not the shape that water takes, there were four hundred people milling near enough to see it and to remember it badly for the remainder of their lives. It rose not as a wave but as a long low wall that mimicked the shore. It smoothed itself with a gesture that was intimate and lazy. Children screamed because it seemed like fun and then screamed because it was not. The wall moved one half-pace onto the land and then stopped, perfectly matched to the curve of the dock. It held. It was as if a lake had decided it would rather be a different sort of lake for a moment.

Liora dropped the small pack she had packed. She ran. She saw the willow in her hand and did not remember taking it but she must have; it had the familiar weight above her wrist. She raised it because some gestures are older than your reasons for making them.

The water spoke in the sound of all the water Liora had ever drunk. It said: Do you hear the drum now. It said: Here is your ear, pressed to me. It said: Why would we not try to be new. And then it stopped saying everything and lurched and threw itself back down so suddenly that all the boats, even those tied tight, crashed and banged and the dock’s old ropes snapped and men reached for children and their feet slipped, and for a moment it was chaos, pure and messy.

Liora stood with her staff out, and she did nothing and everything with it. She did not know the name for the gesture she made. It was something like hello and something like sit. The willow sang under her hands. It is possible to remind a thing what it is. Perhaps that is what she did. People stopped shouting. The water drew itself down. There were still splashes where there shouldn’t be, little shining puddles cupped in handprints on the dock. Bramble barked at the puddles and tried to lick them back into the larger water. He sneezed and glared at his nose as if it were to blame.

“They’re saying,” someone said, breathless, “they’re saying it’s the Black Spire. They’re saying Vesper.”

“Stop saying names and pull the old man up,” Tamsin shouted, voice cutting the market clean. The guard captain hadn’t needed to tell her; she had been moving before the water did. She came up beside Liora and did not ask what Liora had seen because she could read it all in her daughter’s face.

“I’m going,” Liora said, very quietly. “Mother. I’m going and I want you to pretend you didn’t hear me decide it now, and that I decided it after you told me no, and that I obeyed you all my life and it went fine and that this is not the first time I will disobey.”

Tamsin’s mouth did that thing where it held words back by holding very still. She breathed in through her nose and out, and then she reached and pulled a twig out of Liora’s hair because of course there was a twig in Liora’s hair. She held the twig like it meant something. It did.

“You will not go alone,” Tamsin said. “And you will not go today. You will take Corin, and Elyse, and two from the river knights if Shade can spare them. You will take food. You will write me letters even if the letters have to come in on trout. And you will not, not, speak an agreement to anything without letting me say the wrong thing about it first.”

“I am leaving now,” Liora said. “If I leave later there will be a later after later and then someone will be dead whom I love and that will be the thing after which I cannot move. I have to go while I still have motion. I will take Bramble. I will take the willow. Corin will come if he is the sort who comes; I think he is. Elyse will not; she will be insulted you asked her. Shade will let the river knights go if you look at him as you do when you think he is being heroish. That’s a real word. It should be. Look: I will come back in three days if I can’t make a path.”

Tamsin laughed because Larry at the fish stall shouted, “Heroish isn’t a word, Princess!” He had good ears, that man. He wrapped a fish in paper and threw it to Bramble who caught it with a dismaying skill for someone who was supposed to be a companion and not a wild animal. Bramble trotted in a circle with the fish and his rope and nearly strangled himself because joy and food and ropes were too much for any one animal.

“Three days,” Tamsin said. “Four and I’ll come after you with reeds in my hair like a madwomen.”

“I would know you by your hands anywhere,” Liora said.

Tamsin put both those hands on Liora’s cheeks and kissed her forehead and then she stepped back and spoke to the air in a very particular tone that meant she was speaking to the old wood and to the small gods in the mortar as much as to the people. “You will not fail to return our daughter,” she said, as if the walls were responsible. The walls rustled, embarrassed but consenting.

Liora slung the pack back on her shoulder. It had been packed two hours. Bramble circled once and put his little paws exactly where they had to go for them to be moving together three heartbeats later. They went not to the road that most took to the north — the road that went along the river and then up into the passes like a thread going through buttons — but to the older path, the one that went beneath the alder trees in a whispering half-tunnel and then into the old quarry lands where the ground held fossils of fish that had learned to pretend to be leaves. Liora liked that way. She preferred to walk where things had been pretending for a long time. It made you honest. Or maybe it only made you wary, which is another sort of honesty.

They did not look back at the castle because sometimes it is easier not to. They did not look back at the lake because the lake would be doing that performance where it pretended to be fine. The reeds made their soft teeth-chatter. The willow stick hummed, a thread that grew more taut the further north they went, though there was no reason it should. Bramble loped as if his paws were kissing each new piece of dirt as a personal favor.

She saw the omen at the edge of the quarry: a hawk sitting on a stone and not minding them at all. Hawks mind you. That is what they are for. This one looked like a thought that had turned to bone and feather because it was tired of being thought. It watched her with all its regard, and that, more than the lake’s new tricks, made her feel hairline cracks in her certainty. She stopped and lifted her hand like she was about to speak to a person. “Hello,” she said, stupidly.

The hawk spoke. It said, in a voice like shale, “You’re late,” and then turned into itself and became a puff of dust because sometimes that is what words do to a body. Bramble leapt and sneezed because he had tried to bite the air where a bird had been. Then he looked smug, as if he’d succeeded.

“I will say this,” Liora told the willow. “Not many people have hawks complaining to them about their tardiness. Add that to my list of regrets if I get to have any.”

The northern path opened exactly as it always had, which felt like love. She felt, as she passed the threshold of alder step to stone step, that she would learn the new way to breathe. She felt Vesper’s voice still in her throat. She knew the other princess had the upper hand because she had just reached into Liora’s dream like a woman reaching into an oven to adjust a loaf. But she also knew what it was to hold a stick of wood that remembers a seed. She knew what it was to have a dog who found his way home by simply deciding that home is exactly wherever you are together.

“Bramble,” she said, though he was right there. “We will stay ourselves. That is all we have to do. We keep being ourselves, and we don’t let her give us other names.”

Bramble looked up at her, cross-eyed with happiness, with something like: yes. yes. That I can do.

The wind in the quarry sang an old song. It was a song without words and without a melody that any man could carry; it moved in and out of the ribs of the mountain and made a sound like a long exhale. It had been there before the first princess was born. It would be there after this had been done or had failed. Liora put her comfort in that, because she was human and she would look for any place to put her comfort where it would remain for a finger-width of time.

She walked, and the path climbed, and sooner than she wished, the trees thinned to stunted pines, their needles like comb-teeth, old resin tears caught in the bark. Once the wind lifted her hair. Once she felt the ground pulse like it had a desire to be nearer the sky. Once she had to put her hand out and rest it on a boulder with a fossil of a fish leaf locked into it, and the stone was warmer than it had any right to be, as if it had been near a hearth.

At the place where the quarry steps became the first switchback that no one had ever liked, there was a woman sitting on a pack studded with copper rivets, braids lying like bracelets over her shoulders. Elyse. Of course Elyse had come, just to prove Liora wrong. Her mouth was a decision. She raised one eyebrow, and there was humor in it and warning. Beside Elyse, Corin, who had a brow like a door lintel and a way of looking at the world that made it change its mind. He lifted his hand.

“We thought you’d try for early,” he said. “Shade sends the river knights tomorrow because he likes to make an entrance. We left because we like to be where the story is before it begins to be told wrong.”

“You’re both ridiculous and useful,” Liora said. Elyse snorted, but the sound made a smile in her throat.

“We’re only coming because if you go up there without people you’ll say something like heroish again and I’ll die on the spot,” Elyse said. “I have a weak constitution for poor vocabulary choices.”

“Heroish,” Corin repeated, and nodded, as if considering the shape of the new word. “It might be used, if one were careful.”

“Don’t encourage her,” Elyse said. Then she stuck out her hand. Liora took it. It felt like a line you throw to someone. It felt like a promise you might return with. It felt like the first chapter pretending to be the second one already, because sometimes you misnumber the ones that matter. The sky hung over them like a lid not yet properly fitted to the pot.

Bramble walked under Elyse’s hand and she pretended she did not mean to let it touch him, and then she did, and then she put both hands into Bramble’s fur boldly and made a sound that could only be made when touching a puppy: oh. oh. He looked like he had been touched by the sun.

“We go then,” Liora said. “Because if we stand here too long I’ll start to talk. And if I talk too long I’ll start to be afraid.”

“We were afraid when we woke up,” Corin said. “It makes no difference. We go with it in our pockets, like bread.”

They went up into the gray with their fear and with their small jokes and with a dog who believed the journey was a long play invented for him alone. Behind them, down in the green-cupped village and in the white-shouldered castle, the lake thumped a patient drumbeat, counting something that nobody had agreed was a number yet. Ahead, northward, there was a bright stain on the sky, green and shaky as certain happinesses, and above it all, the old, old air moved and did not think any of them important. But in the mouths of the new winds the name Vesper curled like a leaf. Liora felt it slide along her neck. She did not quicken or slow her step for it. She held the willow with its hum, and she walked like someone who had not been given the courtesy of postponement. Her hand, when it brushed against Elyse’s, did not shake. It only looked as if it might start to, later, if there were time.

They began with the small business of walking, which is the same in any world even when the sky mutters to itself and the bones of the mountain click as if resetting. The path shouldered up and around in a steady patience that would have been dull if not for the smell of iron in the air and the way the light to the north kept shifting like a bruise deciding what color to be. Bramble ran reconnaissance on everything three steps ahead, which meant he discovered every prickly plant by embracing it with the whole of his ridiculous body and then looking at Liora as if she had personally invented burrs. Elyse walked as if the slope had been her idea and now she was irritated by her own cleverness; her braids knocked gently against her cloak like a metronome for the day. Corin liked the land, and the land, obliged to be polite back to a man who was polite to it, offered him a firm purchase, except when it didn’t, and then Corin would simply stand and wait five breaths until the stone remembered itself and stopped sliding around under his boots. Liora felt the hum in the willow adjust by degrees as the hours passed and they climbed, not growing louder, but shifting registers the way a throat clears before saying something important.

At the bald saddle below the first long ridge, they stopped to drink where a trickle ran out of a seam like a vein that had decided to try being a creek. The water tasted faintly of nails and fern, which is not to be ungrateful; sometimes you want your water to remind you that a mountain is made of something more stubborn than sweet. Liora crouched and cupped her hands and let the cold bite. Then she bent and licked one wrist like a cat because there is no proper way to be sure you’re awake except to let the body say so. When she lifted her head there was a skein of geese low over the pass to the west, and in the middle of their voices she thought she heard a thin chord that didn’t belong to any bird she’d ever known. She looked to Corin and he was already squinting at the sky, as if the light contained a message and he had to find the one place it did not expect him to look.

“If the Spire had only taken the sky, I’d have been less concerned,” he said, serious as the last knot on a net. “The hills are changing underfoot. We heard it on the Ash Plain. You take three steps and your fourth is a refusal. Then the ground is embarrassed and tries to make up for it. It throws itself up to you and you stumble forward like a drunk who has been helped.”

“Don’t pretend you’ve never been helped by the earth like that,” Elyse said, smoothing her thumb along the ridges of her palm as if the map of her life were printed there and she was revising it. “I remember a year when we couldn’t get any man to go to harvest without retying all their boots. Everyone was walking like the grass had become a river and we were the stones.”

“It’s like language,” Liora said, half to herself and half to the willow. “If you say a word too many times, it stops meaning what it meant. The Spire is saying the word earth so loudly the earth is forgetting what it is, or else it’s remembering some older meaning none of us have learned yet.”

She pulled her small packet from the top of the pack while they rested, more out of habit than necessity, and touched the folded paper that held the Night-Tears. She did not open it. Beneath the seeds, she had tucked a bit of charcoal and a thin slice of scrap parchment. She wrote in a hand learned under her mother’s strict eyebrows: We are well, for values of well that apply to hills that shrug. The light is a green I do not have a word for. Corin is a piece of good furniture you could stand on to reach a jar on a high shelf. Elyse disapproves of words I invent but only the ones that sound like words I love. Bramble attempted to adopt a hedgehog and failed. If the river knights catch us up, give them my patience and keep yours for yourself. Then she rolled the scrap and slid it into a hollow stem from last summer’s reed she’d brought for exactly that purpose. She made a small hole in the damp earth where the trickle pooled, pressed the reed down, and whispered, “For the trout, if they’re feeling lettered.” It is not a sure method, but the river has always been nosy.

The next stretch went under wind that had a logic unlike the usual logic. It did not blow across them; it moved along the ridge like someone sweeping a broom in a long, even stroke. The grasses leaned and then righted themselves, remembering their manners. Liora felt her hair lift once and then settle as if an unseen hand had been checking whether she’d grown. They came up over a lip of stone into a little basin and stopped together because somebody had put a trick into the world there. It was a patch of air with no weather in it, perfectly still, as if the day had a skipped heartbeat. A cloud blew toward it and became a different shape as it crossed, leaner, drawn out, and the shadow it cast on the stones below took on a brighter edge. Corin tossed a pebble and it fell slowly through that patch, changing its mind about speed, as if it had been told a story that made it reconsider its life’s choices. Bramble leapt after the pebble and rose like a bread roll. His paws churned in patient indignation and he looked at Elyse with a betrayed expression that said: You did something to the ground because you love me too much.

“Don’t have ideas,” Elyse said, and caught him neatly by the harness at just the spot where dogs forget to be hurt and remember they are loved. “If you float away I’ll have to go up and get you, and I’ve only brought one pair of good boots.”

“It will be more of this the nearer we get,” Corin said, testing the edges with the tip of his staff, which was not willow and did not hum but knew a thing or two about stubbornness. “Saeth said he tied rocks to his feet. He told no lies.”

Liora put the willow out and the air answered. It hummed the way a bottle hums when you run a finger round its rim, and where she moved it the slow-patch learned her shape. She did not have a theory. She only made the motion she had made at the dock when the lake had thought about being a wall and then changed its mind. The word for it had not been coined; that is not uncommon when you are in the habit of doing the thing you are too young to name. The air adjusted, grew less syrup-thick. The pebble sped up. Bramble put his foot down and found a floor where every floor ought to be. They crossed, not disrespecting the strangeness, but declining to be bullied by it, and when they stepped out on the far side everything snapped back into the proper argument between gravity and defiance.

It was there, beyond that basin, that they first saw the glow like a bruise become a real thing with edges. The Black Spire—only no one with eyes would have called it black if all they knew of it was what it was now. It had been a pillar once, a tooth of basalt with old nests of wind knotted around it, and the witches and wanderers of the north had made their bargains at its foot, no more and no less. Now there was a latticework clinging to it, a scaffolding of light that looked like the inside of a lantern taken apart and set back up by a careless god. From this distance the structure made the Spire seem not taller but wider, as if it had finally decided to occupy all the space it had been promised. The air around it had the quality of glass that has been blown and is cooling: that slightly shifting certainty, that shimmer like heat over a road even though there was no heat.

“It’s a temple to a new verb,” Elyse said, low, because sometimes words can wound the throat if you put too much mistrust into them and speak too loudly. “I hate it. I have never liked temples to verbs.”

“It is a work,” Corin said, not admiring, not condemning. He was counting in his head how at that distance the ladders must be arranged, how the blocks of old basalt would have had to be cut away so that nothing fell on the wrong head. He hadn’t been asked to build it and so he made a ritual of not guessing what tools had been used.

A pair of figures came out from behind a rock where they’d been shoveling the wind into sacks so it would not go to waste, which is the kind of thing that passes for ordinary work in the north when strangeness has had time to make itself a nest. They were not witches—no felt hats, no smell of rosemary or horsehair—but they had the restless look of people who sleep badly because their thoughts kick them in the ribs. One wore a sheath for a whisk that hung from her belt as if it were a blade. The other had the shoulders of a mason and the eyes of a puppy who had been told to guard the world and did not understand how large the job was.

“You’re out of Woodlake,” the mason said, as if the air had written on Liora’s forehead in a neat hand. “If you are selling your steadiness we’ll buy a bottle.”

“Steadiness grows wild where we live,” Liora said, because she could not help herself and because the mason’s ears had the exact angle of Saeth’s and she felt like being kind to anyone who might have been his cousin. “We don’t bottle it. We teach ourselves to drink from the jug.”

“You shouldn’t go that way,” the whisk-woman said, nodding toward the bare slope that led to a pass Liora would have chosen for its honesty. “The Glean is there, and the Glean has been arguing with itself for days. If you speak where the wind can hear, it takes that word down into the rocks and brings it back up at you with teeth. We lost a boy to an adjective last week. He said forever in the wrong tone. The echoes held him in place until they forgot what they were doing and let him drop.”

“We can go along the sheep-path,” Corin said, relief and worry in the same line of his mouth. “It takes longer. We will not like it because the stones put their knees in our back and demand we tell them stories.”

“The stones here are lonely,” the whisk-woman said, and let the handle of her whisk slide into her palm and out again as if she were calming her hands. “They like to be told there used to be ice over everything. They enjoy it when you remind them of their greatness. If you are kind about it, they will not be unkind.”

Liora thanked them with more than a word, and the mason ducked his head and the whisk-woman lifted her whisk as if in salute. When they were gone, Elyse said, “Whisks,” in a tone of deep betrayal and then laughed helplessly because she was a person who liked her tools to understand what they were and a whisk ready for battle was a step too far for her tidy soul.

The sheep-path proved to be exactly what people who are not sheep resent: a sequence of choices that made sense only if your feet were small and your balance had been built by a god who had never seen a plumb line. It ran under a mossed lip and over the mouths of three shallow gullies that had decided to spend this season pretending to be rivers and then skittered along a shelf with a drop on one side that was not death but would have felt like betrayal if you’d gone over it. Bramble managed by making himself not look and by putting his body where Liora’s body had been five heartbeats ago, believing in the magic of repetition. Liora put her palm flat to the rock when they paused somewhere not meant to be stopped on and spoke to the stone without any word at all. It is possible to make the sound you would make if you were a cliff and did not wish to fall to pieces, and she made that sound with her breath, short and soft, and the shelf did not grow wider but it did not narrow.

When afternoon leaned toward evening they came into a pocket of old birches that had decided, stubborn as saints, to live there despite the wind’s poor behavior. The white skins made the light kinder, and the ground, out of politeness, grew a little bit of soft grass. They made a meal that would count as supper if one had not been introduced to gravy at some point in one’s life: bread that had been stepped on twice inside the pack and honey with needles in it from the north-man’s stall and a piece of cheese that had chosen to sweat and did not mind that choice. Bramble, who had carried his fish this whole time in his mind, settled for a smear of everything and a stick he pretended was a bone of a god. Liora put her hand on the willow and then on the ground in a line, making her small net of not-spells and not-prayers that she had learned without anyone admitting they had taught her. The birches answered with a shiver that was also a hello.

Night in the mountains is a person who does not care that you are a princess. It climbs into your blankets. It steps on your chest with cold feet and then forgets it meant to say sorry. The Spire’s green pulsed through the trunks as if the corners of their camp were the numbers on a slow watch. Liora lay awake longer than she would have liked, counting through all the tiny noises she had no business counting, until she was so tired her thoughts softened at the edges and her body took her without consulting her mind. The dream came edged in metal, which is how you know someone else is leaning on the doorframe of it. She was back on the dock and Vesper was there again, but this time Vesper had mud on her skirts and her hair had been braided by a practical person. It made her look younger, and that made her look more deliberate, and Liora resented the strategy.

“You’ve no talent for sleeping without a guard at the door,” Vesper said, conversational as if they’d met over tea in a friend’s kitchen. “I like that in a person. You would not do well in a palace where everyone pretends to nap and actually count each other’s spoons.”

“Do you visit everyone,” Liora said, “or am I special in the particular way that makes life inconvenient. I am trying to be flattered, but you are turning the rivers back and I have only four hands.”

“You would have done this anyhow,” Vesper said, as if Liora had offered an apology for something that required none. “You were always going to walk up after me. It is better to talk now while our feet are not in the same place. When your boots are standing where mine have, your mouth will be a different instrument. I would like to try my song in you before that.”

“I am not your hollow bone,” Liora said, and she wanted to be angrier at the way Vesper smiled because it was not the smile of a villain who liked to gloat it was the smile of a girl who had chosen a hill and climbed it and now was surprised to find that at the top there was wind and not a crown. Bramble, asleep beside her body, must have heard some of the shape of these not-words because in the dream he came and stood between Liora and Vesper and that was ridiculous because he was small and Vesper was not and yet the air preferred him and put its head on his back like he was a lap.

“You are very sweet,” Vesper told the dog, and something in her voice softened into something without sharp corners. Then she looked back up and the softness sharpened because that was exactly what it would do. “Liora. I am not trying to put a bridle on you. I am trying to put a bridle on the world. There’s a difference. It will go better if you are not in my way. Come up when you like. Bring your stick. Bring that boy with the door-brow, the one who will be useful when stones take offense. Bring the woman with the braids so she can say no to you when you have wandered too close to admiration. We will make a shape out of our argument and it will keep the planet from breaking like a plate dropped by an anxious hand. If we are lucky, it will break elegantly. I am, at heart, a generous person.”

“I know what you are at heart,” Liora said, and she dragged at her mind to find the right word and did not because the right word was in a language that had not yet found her, and she hated that Vesper made her feel young in the one way that had nothing to do with how many years any person has had. “You want to remake the floor because you do not like that it is slanted. You have not considered that most of us have learned to walk on it and that we have turned our unsteadiness into a gift, into dancing. You will take away all our awkward grace.”

“Grace is overpraised,” Vesper said, and the dream wobbled and dropped into the dark like a bucket into a well because the mountain had rolled in its sleep and Liora woke with the taste of green in her throat. Bramble breathed at her cheek in the uncomplicated way of animals who have made one decision and will make it for the remainder of their lives. Elyse snored once and then refused to admit it even to herself. Corin slept on his side with his hands in his belt, a quirk of men who grew up in houses where someone might take what they wanted if they were not careful.

They broke camp before the light had made all its arguments, because mountains are kinder before the day remembers it could become hot. The sheep-path gave up pretending to be a path and was honest about being a suggestion. The birches let them go with a sentiment Liora could not put into any word she wanted to write down because it was fondness mixed with reluctance mixed with a small ungenerous wish that they might turn back just so the birches would be the ones to have kept them safe. Beyond, the world opened into a shallow bowl of rock and scrub and low thorn where a woman sat on an overturned bucket beside two hives that had been built into the mountain itself, combs sunk into the crevices like books into a shelf. The bees moved in peculiar figure-eights. Liora breathed in and the air had the caramel-bitter of buckwheat and the knife of resin.

“Do they fall when you light them,” Elyse said dryly under her breath, and then ducked when a bee took offense, because bees are never fans of sarcasm.

“They do as they please,” the woman said, without turning her head, and Liora knew at once that she was one of the old witchers of the north, not because she wore anything that claimed it, not because she had a staff or a bunch of rosemary tied to her belt with red thread, but because the mountain had the look of having agreed to sit with her out of respect and maybe a little fear. “It’s you, then. The one with a lake in her pocket.”

“I have a jug,” Liora said, and the woman smiled but did not show her teeth which told Liora more than if she had. “We were told the Glean is unkind to words.”

“As are most places that have been told what to be for too long,” the witcher said. She tapped the side of the hive with her nail and a different note answered from within, a small bell whose clapper had been oiled. “Vesper has not only opened the Spire. She has opened the Resonatory under it. It is an old room. It teaches anything inside to learn the song that the sky sang when everything began. The song is not meant to be sung by people. People who listen to it too long either stand up taller or fall over and take the room with them when they go. She has set it ringing. That is what you hear when the river runs wrong. It is the planet trying to hum along. It is doing a poor job. Planets have no ear for music.”

“How long have you been sitting here,” Corin asked, and his respect made his voice quiet.

“Since before your grandfather wanted to marry the sea,” the witcher said, not as a riddle but because she could not help but put time into family. “I’ve seen a Spire go dark and take three years to be lit. I’ve seen men try to stop it with hammers. They broke their hammers and their hands and went away praising the noise and cursing it in the same breath. I have honey that will make you see the color of wind if you lick it off a knife. I have honey that will make you remember your mother’s anger click when you shut a door. I have none that will make you safe. But I can tell you where the argument in the Glean is thinner. Go under the black rock shaped like a bear. When you come to the place where the wind tries to be your father, befriend it and then betray it quickly. And do not let the mountain make you believe you were born for the sole purpose of being a witness.”

“I’m not fond of betrayal,” Liora said. “I’m not sure I would make a good partner for it.”

“Then trick the wind into being your sister instead,” the witcher said, and finally turned her head and looked full at Liora and her gaze was a taste of metal against the tongue. “You are very tired. The Spire is a magnet and you are iron. Do not be surprised that you point north. But know you can be turned by a touch. Do not let anyone but your own hand lay hold of you.”

Bramble stuck his nose toward the hive and then decided this was an arena where bravery would be a bad dog’s kind of bravery. He lay down beside the witcher’s boot and thumped his tail and the witcher, without looking, put her heel against his ribs so he would know he had been counted and approved. Liora exchanged a piece of news for a piece of honey that was the color of a good bruise. The news she gave was that the lake in Woodlake had started trying on different shapes. The witcher took that and set it in her lap as if it were a thing that might begin to move on its own and then she waved them off with the back of her hand with the economy of an old woman who did not need to bless anyone; her existence did enough.

The bear-rock did in fact look like a bear, but only if you had first made your mind up to see bears in rocks in the manner of children and poets. The Glean hove up around them, though that is not what the Glean looked like; it looked like a notch that had been taken out of the world by a god who needed to measure something and had lost the piece. The wind there did not go across or around. It went up from the ground as if the world were a kettle and the lid did not fit. Liora put her mouth to Corin’s ear at one point, which is something she would not usually have done because his ear had the dignity of a plum, and said, “No words.” He nodded and pressed his lips together as if the wind might otherwise go in and rummage through what was stored there.

They moved as if they were not moving, which is the only way to pass a place like the Glean where movement calls attention to itself and the wind wants to applaud. Twice they stepped on words that had been left behind by people who might have thought they were done with them. One word was “almost” and it snagged at Liora’s boot-lace and tried to pull her down into a promise she did not want to make. She stepped out of it the way you step out of a puddle that has become deeper than it promises. One word was “forever,” which lay like a loose board across a gap. Elyse looked at it with ruthless affection, the way you look at a friend who has become inconvenient at a party, and she held out a hand to Liora and they stepped across together, not because the word wanted them to but because their bodies did it as one unit and the word was too surprised to object.

At the far lip of the Glean the wind tried to be their father, exactly as promised, and it said in the tone of fathers everywhere who have learned worry earlier than most, You will be hurt if you continue. Liora leaned into it and thought of the rejoinder that would leave it chastened and then she did not say it because even if it had been a good line the wind would have taken it from her and used it on some child who did not deserve to be bossed. She put her palm up and the wind put its palm against hers and then she ducked and went under as if it were a low lintel and she had been trained from childhood to avoid doorframes that liked to crack skulls. The wind huffed and then went on about its business with dignity. Corin went under as if bowing to an unworthy magistrate. Elyse went under like the letter S.

They came, toward evening, to a place where a piece of wall had grown out of the ground for no reason anyone could name, three courses of old stones with lichen and an arrangement of mason-marks that made Corin smile in his bones. Someone had hung a coat there—the black of the roadmen—and beneath the coat a strip of leather with writing burned into it with a heated nail. It said: Two went up. One fell in love with the green and won’t come back. One is still counting. If you pass him tell him we will set his plate by the stove and he is not to become clever. Corin put his fingers on the marks reverently and then he put his forehead against the stone and Liora looked away because sometimes reverence is not for audience. Elyse read the line about becoming clever and rolled her eyes and said, “Men become clever for the same reason women buy sugar: because they think it will sweeten something that doesn’t want to be sweetened and then it ends up everywhere and you’re sticky all day.” Liora kissed her cheek without planning to. The look Elyse gave her afterward was complicated and interesting and very much like the look of a woman who had not meant to step on a word like forever and had done it and then stepped off again later and still noticed the damp mark on her shoe. They did not discuss it and that was all right for that minute and perhaps not for other minutes to come.

They made their beds that night under a dripstone that had tamed itself into a ledge where no drip had fallen in at least a century. The Spire’s glow was stronger and did not pretend to be anything but a summons. Campfires moved along the far flanks of the valley like eyes. Liora could tell which fires belonged to those who had gone up for the thrill because their flames sawed at the air and the smoke ran in excited lines. There were fires that belonged to those who had been paid in coin and there were fires that belonged to those who had been paid in grief. She put the Night-Tears in the ground by the dripledge and pressed the soil over them firmly because seeds like a firm hand. She poured a spoon of water and then another because you never know what you will regret not watering later. “If we come back this way,” she told them, “be either up or gone. Sleeping seeds give me a worse resentment than men who explain lock mechanisms to me while holding my own keys.”

Bramble took the watch of his choice, which is to say the middle one where nothing rational happens and everything else does, and he did it by sleeping with one paw on each of their ankles so that if someone moved the dog would know right away. Liora lay and listened to the green, which had become a buzzing now, not mechanical, not bee, more like the sound a raven makes in your throat when you try to call it and it decides it will come to you because you are ridiculous and need to be humored. Just before sleep took her all at once there was the sound of a man coming up a slope with no care for stealth and yet no foolish noise either. She sat up so fast her cloak tried to strangle her because it was a garment that resented haste. Corin woke with his hand already on the small hammer that took the place of his temper when he could not find it. Elyse had a knife in her hand before anyone else’s eyes knew to see her hand.

He came into the circle of their watch-light and set down his pack and in the pack’s leather there was a river stitched, which is how you know a knight who rides water when he does not ride horses. He had an oar in one hand and a spear in the other, which is an elegant and absurd way to walk through a mountain. He was young enough to have hope in his eyebrows and old enough to have folded his boyhood and put it away without looking at it lately. He grinned at the dog first, because any man who denies a dog is a man who will deny himself later and should be corrected by the next convenient aunt. Bramble, who knew nothing of knights but knew how to weight a lap, climbed into the knight’s lap like it had been built to his specifications.

“Shade sends regards,” the river knight said, and he sat where Bramble had insisted and the seat became a throne even though it was a rock. “He says to tell the mountain if it trips you it will answer to him and then he laughed like he laughs when he has just put a spear through a fish who thought itself cleverer than any man alive. I am Tern. I came early because a roadman passed our boathouse and his letter had news in it that would go stale if the sun touched it twice. They say Vesper has called a wind from under the Spire that counts. It is counting down.” He opened his hand and there on his palm was a little disc of hammered tin that had been rubbed with charcoal and counted upon by a nervous thumb. There were nine marks in a circle and one had been smudged as if it had been erased by a rude hand. “They say tomorrow it will be eight. Shade says to tell you if you mean to stand there and say no you had better have the kind of no that does not blow away in a strong breath.”

Liora put her fingers to the tin and the tin was warm and then it was cold because she was frightened and her body had not known it properly until now. The mountain made the sound of an animal remembering it was hungry. The green light shifted and put a shawl around their shoulders and then threw it off again as if it had been scolded for acting familiar. She looked at Corin and Elyse and Tern and at Bramble, who had settled on Tern’s knees with the certainty of saints, and she thought she would try to sleep again because there would be less time to be afraid if she did.
