The willow lay along her spine like a hand. The world counted and somewhere, in the notch of an old drum, the lake kept time with the sort of patience that is not kind and not unkind, but simply is. She closed her eyes and kept them closed even when the wind said her name in a voice she might once have called beautiful and would never call anything again except hungry.

Morning did not so much arrive as rub its eyes and sit up with a groan, and every rock for half a league made the same slow sound of finding its joints. The green light from the Spire had softened while they slept, as if it too had needed to blink. Tern was already on his feet when Liora pushed out of her blanket, the tin disc on his palm held up to the light like a small moon being judged. One of the charcoal tics had become a smear that would not quite wipe away, and in its place the emptiness felt like a mouth breathing. He turned it so it would catch the shadow of his thumb and looked relieved to see that the missing mark had not crept back in the night and made liars of them all.

“It took one,” he said in the tone of someone announcing that a rival had stolen a spoon. “Shade says he’s never liked a count he cannot argue with. This one does not argue back. It simply goes on with its business.”

Liora put her hand over his and the metal kissed her skin with the faintest sting, like a nettle that wanted to be polite. She did not think there was a device in it any more than there had been a device in the lake when it threw itself on the dock like a friend who has learned wrestling. It felt like the tin was being taught to be less tin. The willow leaned in its quiet way toward the disc and did not hum so much as clear its throat delicately. In the long list her mother had taught her—Count spoons. Count people. Count the cows twice if they are all in the same field because cows have ambitions—Liora had never been taught what to do about a count that did not belong to anyone and still ruled the air.

They ate a poor breakfast with the solemnity of a feast. Bread, which had decided in the night to lose an argument with damp. Cheese, which did not care what anyone thought of it. Honey from the witcher that stained their tongues briefly with the color of pewter and then changed its mind and let them have the color of summer. Bramble disposed of pebbles and twigs with dedication and eyed the cheese as if it were a badger he would eventually befriend through persistence and flattery. They stamped the last of the fire to ash and Liora, because it felt proper, told the ash, “Stay, if you can,” and the ash said nothing because ash is the least sentimental substance in the world.

They kept to the line of the wall that had climbed out of the earth like an old thought that wanted to be looked over one more time. The man who had promised not to become clever had not left the vicinity; they found him one bend on with his back against a slab and his eyes as steady as a pair of stones in a river. He did not look up as they came near; he was counting, and not in numbers that belonged to money or sheep. He counted in breaths that forgot where their edge was. Liora heard the rhythm first and then the numbers under it and then the absence of any number that would be useful to a merchant. He was saying the days since he had come up, and the days since any person had tried to touch him, and the days since the wind had said his name and he had said no.

“Do you want a piece of bread,” Elyse asked, and because she spoke without trying to be kind, only trying to be correct, he looked up and took it from her hand and forgot once where his count had been and flinched at the lost place like a man who has been told to stop in the middle of a drumbeat. Tern sat down beside him as if they were cousins and put the tin on his knee. The counter’s gaze slid to it and snagged and he made a small hurt sound through his teeth.

“It will be eight before dark,” he said. “Eight is a fair number. It makes neat halves and quarters, and when you split it you feel you’ve done something tidy. It pretends to be friendly, and in that it is treacherous, because it is no more our friend than nine, which is a boastful number, or seven, which is a number that believes in its own stories. I have been trying to convince the wind to stop counting there, because eight makes men put their tools away and tell themselves there is time, and then they go to sleep and never wake up. The wind keeps learning the wrong lessons from me.”

“What happens when it reaches nothing,” Corin asked, and then did the politeness of saying, “Forgive me. We’ve none of us ever liked to say that word.” He tapped the stone with his knuckles and the stone answered him with the hollow ring of a thing that is thinking about counting too.

“It will try to do the new thing,” the man said, and wiped the heel of his hand along his jaw as if there were a word stuck to it and he’d like it gone. “When a child gets to the end of a set of stairs he will sometimes leap. It’s like that. There are those who will tell you it will be like unclasping a necklace that has been strangling our necks for a thousand years. There are those who will tell you it will be like opening your own mouth and pulling your heart out to see if it still moves. Vesper says both on alternate days, and she believes herself each time.”

Liora crouched. She had not noticed until she was close that the man had a string around his wrist, just as the boy at the gate had. It had been tied too tight and had bitten him in. She slid a nail under the knot and loosened it without asking. He did not blush at the kindness and that told her he had been up here longer than his beard suggested. “Will you come back down when your count is done,” she said, and waited through the panic that rose in him like heat off a forge.

“If I come down it will mean I have not mistaken the wind’s voice for the voice of God,” he said, as if he were reading from a letter echoed back to him. “It will mean my wife will know she is a widow only in the way she likes, not in the way people in this part of the world mean it. It will mean I will confess that I cannot keep a thing from happening by naming the steps that lead to it, and I have always liked to believe in the strength of names.”

“Come down for your supper,” Tern said, practical as salt. “Your plate is by the stove and your friends told me to tell you to wash your hands before you touch it. There’s a child who sits on the stoop who asks if the green is as green up here as it looks from there. He only has the one question and he has been saving it for you. If you don’t come down I will tell him it is half the green he thinks, because spite is good for the young.”

The man smiled despite himself, and in that smile Liora saw a person who had once been able to dance on a slant floor and not worry about grace. He stood very carefully as if he were afraid he had become the hinge on which the mountain swung and did not want to creak. When he had proven his bones still belonged to him, he lifted his eyes toward the Spire and bowed to it like a fellow with respect for a thing he does not admire. “Keep your words,” he said to Liora, “on a string you can pull back. She is good at stealing. She will not take from your pockets. She will take with compliments.” He started down the path with the walk of a man who has remembered he is very tired and very hungry, and at the curve he looked down and called, “If you see the one who fell in love with the green, tell him I said he is not to be clever either and that I am not angry, only disinclined to forgive a man who chooses a color over a spoon.”

They did not encounter the green-eyed deserter. They did meet three youths with bees stitched in gold along the sleeves of their jackets, which would have looked like a joke if the jackets had not been smeared with real pollen. The youths had been given a task and were taking it devoutly: they were catching loose words in long cotton bags and smacking the bags smartly against rocks until the words were stunned enough to be carried to their new hive. Each time they opened a bag, a sentence would fly out and make a bright angry sound like a letter caught in a door. One of the sentences said, Let me go you fools, and Elyse, who had been about to praise their ingenuity despite herself, shut her mouth and went fierce.

“You do not bag a sentence like that,” she told the tallest, who wore his hair with a carelessness that had to be practiced. “You put it down on the table and pour it tea and tell it your friend died once and the sentence will sit and look at you and become quieter. Then you can use it again. You do not beat it against a rock. Words remember. Treat them as if they had a spine.”

The tall youth looked chastened and then made a face as if being told to be gentle with an abstract thing had pressed the bruise of his own daily fear too hard. He took the bag down and opened it and the sentence shot out and stood in front of Elyse like a crow that will come to your shoulder if you do not look at it directly. It tilted its head and thought about pecking and then it hopped and settled itself inside the open space of her hand, which is a thing some sentences will do if you have never lied to yourself about why you are using them. Elyse shut her fingers. “Sit,” she told it, as if it were a dog. It did.

There were camps now, not just the scatter of small fires but proper camps like a braid of thought woven around a difficult idea. One camp belonged to the masons, and in it men and women with poor knees and excellent backs whittled the corners of blocks that hummed when you touched them, which is a reason to be gentler with corners than you might be. One camp belonged to the witchers and there were charms hung like laundry between poles and every charm had something in it that had once been alive and had given up gracefully. One camp belonged to those who came because they loved spectacle. There were banners there that swore by colors and made no mention of names, and Liora felt a homesick ire rise up in her throat, because color is what we have left when we have spent all our names and she did not like to see it put to wages. Tern walked through all of it with the bored air of a man who has escorted casks past a great many parties and knows he will do so through to the end of his days and will neither join nor condemn.

At the edge of the last of the makeshift cities there was a long low building that had not been there three days ago because the grass under it still had the shape of its former intent. It was all glass that had found a way to become a wall again after years of having forgotten how, and through the glass Liora saw a room lined in blue stone. Men and women at the far end stood at a bank of things that were not quite instruments and not quite dolls. They moved their hands through frames of light and their hands came away smelling like rain. In the very center, beneath a dome that had been polished to the verge of offense, a column of not-light rose out of the floor and made the hairs on Liora’s arms leap to attention. For a breath she was back at the lake, but this time the view did not close itself off when she moved. She touched the glass with her forefinger and the glass took her pulse and held it to its surface like a coin pressed under a piece of paper and rubbed with graphite.

“She has opened another of the rooms,” Corin murmured, his mouth so near the glass that his breath came back at him with a stranger’s smell. “We were told there were rooms under the Spire where the old ones taught themselves to be worse than gods and better than accidents. That one’s a tuner. It’s teaching itself how to make a note that will untie a knot.” He looked ill now, not because he did not love work but because he did love it and this was work that took the floor out from under his feet and told him swimming was work too and how had he not known.

“Doors,” said a woman at Liora’s shoulder, and Liora realized she had come up and stood very close indeed to a person who did not look like she meant to ever be far away from any event. The woman’s hands had scars on the palms that meant she had once grabbed a rope that did not want to be grabbed, and the rope, being a rope, had taught her its opinions. “They’re all doors, these rooms. We had to kick at this one until it decided kicking was conversation. I nearly broke my foot, which made me laugh, which made the room offended in a way that told me it had a sense of humor it wasn’t using.”

“Does it matter to it if we go in and admire the furniture,” Elyse asked. She had put her palms flat to the glass as a test of whether the room would be rude enough to touch back. It did not. It let her feel nothing at all, which was a different sort of rudeness. “Will it be kinder if we tell it it’s pretty.”

The woman grinned, the kind of grin that made Liora think of her mother’s friend who could turn any lock with the hairpins she wore for decoration. “It will be kinder if you do not expect kindness. It will be more honest if you address it like a beast who could chew your hand off but is too full to bother if you speak nicely. Are you the wood lake girl. Vesper says you have the sort of face people would confess to and then regret. She likes regret. It makes people tidy.”

“You tell your princess,” Liora said, feeling the heat that came up her neck when she was told she had a face that did not belong to her, “that if she wanted my face here she should have come down and asked for it in daylight. She preferred the dark. That tells me the number of her bravery.”

“She prefers the stage where her audience listens,” the woman said without malice. She had turned her injured hands over and was tracing the scars with the tenderness people reserve for proof they have lived. “She likes a bowl to speak into. The mountain is a good bowl. The sky will carry her voice to the snow. You will go up and say no in the way of people who have been taught to say no the first time they are asked and to say yes only after they’ve decided on their own. That will bring her more joy than if you had said yes at once. Opposition makes a shape from nothing. If she likes you she will try to make you into a hinge.”

“I am not a hinge,” Liora said. “I am wood. I may be planed smooth but I remember seed.” It was foolish to tell that to a stranger in this place, and yet the stranger’s eyebrows jumped in the way Corin’s did when someone used a name for a tool correctly, and she nodded as if given a secret handshake that had been out of fashion for a hundred years.

They stepped away from the glass because it is never wise to stare too long at anything that pretends to be empty when it is full, and came into a corridor where a rope sang. It did so without being touched. It was strung between two posts that were not exactly posts—more the notion of standing—and the rope was plaited of something that had once looked like hair and now looked like iron that had remembered a childhood. The note it made was not a note any throat would want to make, but it threaded itself through Liora’s teeth and then through the willow and tightened. The noise made Tern flinch and then he set his jaw and the jaw was the jaw of a man who has rowed upstream in flood and counted each insult the river had given him and added it to a store of debt he meant to collect when he had time.

“Touch nothing,” Elyse said, which is the line of anyone who has had to clean up after men who pretend curiosity is a virtue unshared by others. Bramble sat with his occurrence of perfect behavior and made his ears do that little lift they did when he believed he had done something to deserve a fish. He had not. Liora bent without putting her hands near the rope and put her face very close so she could smell it. It smelled like storms and the inside of a library, and that unsettled her more than if it had smelled of blood. Knowledge has always had the ability to be misused, but the rope smelled like a thing that did not understand misuse, only use, and in that she had to respect it even as she wanted to put it in a cupboard and shut the door.

“You made your lake sit down,” said a boy behind them with blue snuff on his nose and a set of calluses that said he had been scolded by flint more than once in his life. “Can you make this stop singing. It sings the tune my brother was given when he went into the river and did not come out, and I don’t want to be told again what I already know.”

“I made the lake remember itself,” Liora said. “I can ask the rope to forget. Whether it does is the rope’s business.” She spoke to it with the palm of her hand, not by touching it—her mother had taught her long ago that if you ask a cat to come you do not pursue it; you make yourself interesting and let the cat claim you. She made herself into the absence of sound for the length of one breath and then for the length of three, and then she let her breath out and the rope gave up a note that was lower and lazier, like a rest in a hymn. The boy cried once, short, and then stuck his fist in his mouth as if he had a tooth loose and did not want anyone to see.

When they came up to the beginning of the black stairs that had been cut into the first skin of the Spire, a woman with a braid of hair so long it could have choked a river stood with a rod and tapped each boot as it passed. Corin watched carefully and saw that she was not counting people; she was telling the stairs the shape of each foot and asking the stone to see them as individuals rather than a mass. Masses are too easy to roll down a hill. Her rod was made of old bronze with a collar of jet, and the jet had a crack in it and through the crack you could see that it had learned to love being broken. She glanced at Liora’s willow and at Tern’s oar and at Elyse’s knives and each time one object showed too much pride she tapped it, and the sound was the sound of a child being told to tuck in its shirt. Liora, who had never in her life obeyed a request to tuck in a shirt unless it pleased her, still found herself standing straighter.

“You will want to stop two turns below the white shelf with the pigeons painted on,” the woman said with a patience that had been purchased at decent cost. “You will not be able to help yourselves. The song is thin there and goes like sugar in tea. If you stop there, leave a part of yourself behind on purpose—a hair, a nail paring, a curse—so that when you come away the cliff does not keep more than its share. There are children that stand there all day licking the air. We push them off when we can. Vesper hates us for that and loves us for doing it when she cannot bear to. Do not leave your dog, for the love of anything you name. The Spire will convince itself it has become his mother.”

“We would burn it down first,” Elyse said in a tone that made the woman look at her properly and decide to like her at once.

The stairs were not innumerable. That was the worst of them. They could be counted, and anything that can be counted can be finished, and the knowledge that there was a top and that in reaching it they would be expected to be ready was a cruelty Liora would have liked to return to its sender. They climbed into light that had the taste of copper pennies. Once a white moth brushed Liora’s cheek and was dragged backward by nothing she could see and turned in the air with an affronted dignity and tried again. Once a ladder leaned past them, made of light exactly as Saeth had said, and three men in harnesses climbed it as if they had always been climbing light. Once a woman in a smear of red paint came down past them without moving any muscle she did not need and said aloud to no one, “We will need another kind of link. We will need a braid that doesn’t mind being forgotten by the hair that made it,” and Corin made a note on his skin in pencil because there was no other paper that would please him more at this altitude.

They stopped two turns below the white shelf with pigeons right where the rod-woman had told them they would, as if the path had leaned out and made a place exactly Liora-shaped, and the song slid around their ankles and their wrists with the tenderness of a snake that has decided not to bite this once. Liora did as she’d been told and pulled a hair and wrapped it around the head of a nail she carried in her pouch, then pressed it into a crack where the stone would think itself clever for hiding it. Elyse set down a curse, but because her curses were beautifully made and had all their seams turned and pressed, the wind could not find its way into it and so the curse sat there like a tidy hen until a passing mason lifted it up and put it in his pocket because it was a good one and he might need it later. Tern swore in the language river-men use when the keel staves and their hands are bleeding and then he cut the oath in half with his teeth and spat one piece to the left and one to the right and the wind had to split to fetch it and they walked through the gap. Bramble put his paw on Liora’s boot to inform her a bee had gotten into his brain and was making him think about soup. She told him no with her eyebrows and he blinked three times and the bee left and went to bother a boy who did not have eyebrows his mother had taught to say no.

The white shelf had been painted with pigeons by someone who had either loved pigeons or hated them and Liora, who had never held a strong opinion on the subject, found herself full of a resentful affection for birds who did not know they were art. There were people there, just as the rod-woman had said, with their mouths open a little, faces relaxed in the way of people who have finally had the noise in their heads matched by a noise outside and found it a relief. Vesper had put a woman there with a bell and a pole and the woman went around and rang the bell in front of every mouth with a beat that said wake, wake, wake, and some did and some did not, and the bell-woman’s mouth tightened in a way that said she would ring the bell until her hand fell off, and then ring it with the other hand. When the bell came near Liora it did not strike, and Liora thought: she told her to spare us this scolding, and the bell-woman’s eyes flicked over and said: do not be flattered. Bramble, to whom bells are either toys or threats with nothing between, growled and then sneezed and the sneeze had a dignity that made two children laugh and then stop, embarrassed, because they had been given a new habit and had not yet learned where not to put it.

They reached the last turn and there, not waiting with ceremony or guard, stood Vesper. There was no crown. There were no bees. She had dirt under her nails. If you were hunting for theatricality you would have to go and find it for yourself and bring it to her, and she would decide whether to keep it. She did not say Liora’s name. She did not say any name. She looked at Liora the way you look at a mirror that you sometimes hate because it shows you what you are doing to your own face.

“You came quicker than I had thought,” she said, and her voice was not winded at all. “Good. We have been busy. You can be shown the proof and then you may say your piece.”

“I have had my ear to the water and my mouth full of your breath since you climbed,” Liora said, and she stepped so that Elyse remained by her shoulder and Corin where he could see the corners of things and Tern with his spear which had been made of oak that had changed its mind and become iron and then back again twice. “I have seen your rooms. I have watched the river men tie rocks to their boots so they would not be flung around by the laughter of the plain. I’ve had a woman who loves witches more than they love themselves tell me you have set the Resonatory to ring. I have stepped through a patch of air that had become an argument. Is there any proof you could show me that could be more than the proof of being here.”

Vesper laughed once, a small sound that went into the rock as if the mountain were a lover she had tapped on the shoulder. “There is the proof of pattern,” she said, and she stood aside so that they could see past her into the mouth of the Spire. It had not had a mouth three months before. Now it had the kind of mouth old things have when they are tired of being closed. The stairs within were not stairs any longer; they were a slope made of interrupted light. It was not color; it was one of those not-lights, but arranged into planks the size of the shoulders of a careful man. It was the sort of thing anyone would be tempted to step onto and then think better of and then step onto anyway because the temptation of not tripping was too much.

Vesper led them without turning to make sure they followed. That angered Elyse irrationally and she did not say anything because she did not wish to watch Vesper turn and collect her words as if they were coins dropped by a careless rich woman. Corin lagged once by a little alcove where a piece of machinery sat that looked like a child’s toy. It was glass spun around a spindle and when you blew across the top of it the glass sang with a human voice. A man was kneeling by it with his ear against it as if to hear a wound knit. He was crying in a fully engaged manner because whatever he had been told to fix was something no tool could reach, and that is the way men who love work cry when they finally are given proof that sometimes there is no work to be done except to stop.

They came into a room that Liora recognized without wanting to from the lake’s first vision. Blue stone. A ceiling polished so diligently it had become insult. At the far end, two figures stood within a cage of light like a net turned inside-out. One of them was reciting the names of colors as if that would keep him where he was supposed to be. The other was counting down in a voice like the road at midnight. A column rose behind them, taller than any column has any right to be, and if you looked aside even a little it did not exist, and if you tried to grab it with your eyes it shoved your gaze down your throat and made it sit there like a badly chewed bite of meat. Along the wall, on low tables, lay maps that made the map in the room at Woodlake look like a child’s paper crown, and Liora’s heart leapt and hated itself for leaping because she adores a neat map more than many better people adore their own children. These maps were not drawn. They were a stitching of laid nerves. The mountain itself had been asked to provide its lines.

“Once,” Vesper said, and the room adjusted itself to a better listening shape as if it had leaned in, “something opened here. It was not a portal and it was not a mouth. It was a forgetting. Alderra forgot itself at this point exactly and began to be something else, and then it remembered itself poorly and was ashamed and put stones over the shame. People built shrines to the shame. That is what we always do. When grief grows its own ribs we hang medals on it and pretend we did that on purpose. The old ones—call them the builders, call them the mothers, call them the idiots with room in their heads for everything but love—made a set of rooms where they could come to push at the world. I have opened them. It was not hard. Locks are for people who wish to think they can stay out. Rooms wish to be rooms.”

“What is it you wish me to see,” Liora asked, and she put her hand behind her and found Elyse’s wrist and wrapped her fingers around it and felt the pulse there insult the notion that anything large could make them small.

“That the count is not me,” Vesper said, and it was the first time she had said anything that felt naked enough to be true. “I am not the song. I am the bell. I did not invent the river; I moved the rock that made the water change its mind. You will call me arrogant because it is easier to hate a person than a room. Do me the credit of hating the correct thing. If you must hate me, hate me later. We are at eight. We will be at seven by the time you have stopped holding your breath. Liora of Woodlake”—she said the name like it was the answer to a riddle that had satisfied her—“if you stand with me we can make the end a good one. If you stand apart we will still make it, but it will be uglier, because you will force me to be interesting, and I do not like being interesting when I work.”

“I have no interest in helping you find a more elegant way to break the dishes,” Liora said, and she was surprised to find her voice smooth and not dripping with all the things she would have liked to pour into it. “If you are not the count, it does not exonerate you from waking it. A man who shakes a sleeping hound and says, see, the hound has always had teeth, is a very fine sort of liar, and I would not trust him with my favorite shoe.”

“Then don’t,” Vesper said, and for the first time her smile looked like it belonged to her and not to her idea of herself. “Trust me with nothing. Bring your staff. Bring your dog. Bring your stubborn mind put together out of reeds and old paper and bake-oven heat. Stand opposite. We will make a shape between us that the world can lean on when it begins to tilt.” She lifted her hand and the note in the room shifted and went through Liora’s mouth and made it open a little. The taste was like ice and iron. It made her think of her mother’s handwriting. It made her think of how it had felt to be told at ten that she would be a cupboard if she kept all her thoughts under lock and key. She swallowed and the taste went down and became something else in her belly that she would have to name later.

Tern had not spoken, and now he did. He spoke like a man who has stood on a boat that was not sure it wanted to be a boat any longer. “If we walk out of here and tell the mountain to sit, Will it sit. If we take our oars and push you off your little island will you fall. If we tell the count to go to hell will it go.”

“If you can say hell in the right tone,” Vesper said, and her eyes slid to him and away because he was not the one she wanted to be speaking to, “you can teach water to burn. I have no interest in stopping you from attempting. The work is already doing the work. I prefer assistance to opposition, but I am not above using opposition like a brick. Stand where you like.”

Corin breathed, finally, like a man who had forgotten it was an option. He laid his broad palm on the blue stone at his hip with the affection of one who speaks to walls at night when there is no person to hear. “There is a weakness where you have cut,” he said, nosily, like a cousin who will not be silent at wakes. “Your light-planks nest badly over that seam. You will fall through if a child jumps. You are proud enough to like to be warned well. Consider yourself warned.”

Vesper’s head tipped. Her mouth did a not-smile that Liora saw and recognized and disliked and could not help admiring because it was like her mother’s when told someone had made a clever mistake. “Thank you,” she said, and it carried no mockery, and at once a woman with a braid like rope and a man with a pencil tied to his wrist leapt into the net of light and fixed the seam as if it had insulted a guest. “You see, Liora. It is much better to have people around who do not wish to be here. They tell the truth as a matter of principle.”

“We’ll choose a place,” Elyse said briskly. She had not gone all small under the weight of the room and Liora took in a breath of her as one breathes at a window. “We’ll choose a place to stand where your noise cannot hide our no. If you want us to save your work from your own cleverness, we’ll send you an invoice. If you want us to keep children from standing in the sugar, we’ll use our bell. If you want us to be your vanity’s polishing-cloth, you may invent a better request.”

Vesper inclined her head as one does when one has been spoken to by someone who knows the exact weight of her own refusal. “There,” she said. “By the column, not under it, where your dog won’t be convinced he is the size of a bear. The count will be six by then. It may be five if the river in the west decides to practice running up hill again. Go and rest where the pigeons are painted. Even saints require soup.” She lifted her hand and the room exhaled them. The light-ladders drew themselves up so they would not be stepped on as if by a child who doesn’t want his toys muddied. Outside, the sky had been stained an earnest green that looked like vigor; you could fool yourself into thinking it was health. The tin in Tern’s hand had grown cooler.

They found a place to make a day’s home under a scarp from which roots trailed like hair washed and left to dry. The camps had learned to give them room not out of courtesy but out of mistrust that had agreed to try the shape of respect for an evening. Corin set stones in a small circle and spoke to them until they consented to be a hearth. Elyse set her knives in a line along the lip of the scarp with their blades toward the mountain, an impoliteness that would be understood by anyone with sense as a sign of watchfulness and not hostelry. Tern went to stand where he could see the river—far to the east, a thread of metal that had taken an oath not to behave normally—and he whistled once in a manner Shade would hear if a heron were the messenger. Liora unwrapped her packet with the seeds she had carried and looked at the little drawing of the bell-shaped bloom with its mouth shut and decided that even here, perhaps especially here, a bell with no mouth belonged.

She pressed three Night-Tears into the thin soil and tamped them down with the pad of her thumb. She told them a story about a boy with a piece of string around his wrist and his insistence that string could keep him from falling away. She told them about a dog who believed he could be the mother of any child if the child consented to be licked. She told them about a lake that had wanted to be a wall and had chosen instead to be a lake. She told them about a princess who did not like being given a place to stand by someone else but would stand there anyway if it meant keeping children’s mouths shut when the sugar sang. The green over the world brightened because it liked stories when they were told by people standing with their backs to a cliff and their faces to the wind. Bramble lay with his chin on Liora’s knee, and when his eyes rolled up to look at her there were a thousand small reflections of the Spire’s light there, which is how you learn what kinds of lights your world has, because there is no mirror like a good dog’s eyes.

Toward sunset, a sound came up from the very bones. It was not the count. It was an announcement. A drumming that had more joy in it than threat, more insistence than grace. Liora felt the beat take the shape of her chest and fit itself there like a hand. The pigeons on the shelf looked as if they might lift. Elyse’s braids knocked like a clock. Corin’s brow learned a new crease. Tern, who was dipping his tin in cold water to make it change its mind about being a witness for a moment, came up fast, water in his beard, and held the disc out like a plate to catch falling bread. There were seven marks left, clean and terrible, and there were not seven, because at that same beat the first of the marks blurred and went dark and made a confession: it had never been a mark, it had been a hole.

The mountain said, as mountains do when no one listens and so they speak to the very few who will, Prepare, and the word did not go into their ears but up through their feet. Liora put her hand on the willow and the willow shivered and became a little more than a stick and a little less than a tree. She did not look for Vesper in the doorway of the blue room. She did not ask the air how many times it had learned to be this particular shade. She looked at her companions and at the dog and she let the count settle in her bones and she named the numbers to herself in the language of her mother’s ledger and of boys tying string. She named them in bread and in apples and in the steps between two stones. There was soup to be heated. There were knives to be sharpened. There were pigeons to not eat. There was a woman with a bell who would come if called and would ring her arm off because it is those with bells who save us. There were two nights perhaps, or one, or half a one.

She slept with all her faults on, because there is no point polishing your conscience when you intend to take it into a place where everything will be scratched. The wind came and it said her name again and she did not open her eyes. It said it prettier and she did not open them. It tried a harsher sound because it had learned a little of her and misapplied its knowledge and she laughed in her sleep because she owned that sound and no one else did. When she woke, the green had grown honest enough to be sickly, and the tin disc had made up its mind to show six. The mountain clicked. Somewhere in Woodlake, a dock creaked and Bramble’s cousins barked at puddles too small to deserve barking. Liora tied her hair back with a piece of cord that had once bound three letters to a trout. She stood up into the day and found it waiting, as days will when they cannot wait any longer.

The count wore six like a ring that fit too well, and everyone on the mountain felt their finger bones under it. Morning stretched itself into something braced, like a beam set under a roof that might decide to sag. Men sat in their shirts and boots and stared at steam as if it might give advice, and women plaited their hair tighter than they needed to, knots made as if to hold in thoughts that might otherwise leap away into the green. Liora woke with her mouth dry and a small sore spot on her cheek where the willow had pressed in the night; it had left a miniature crescent, a reminder that even friends make their marks when you sleep too close. Bramble had made a decision to be a stone and had placed himself across her ankles so that all the dreams that wanted to run away would have to ask him for permission first. When she eased free he rolled to present a ribcage and made the sound that meant he would forgive her for absolutely everything if she engaged with his fur for half a minute with all the intensity of princes at councils. She obliged, and the morning decided it wouldn’t be able to knock her entirely awry while she still smelled like dog.

It turned out that Shade had sent two, after all. The second river knight came up with a little boat on his back, a thing so narrow and quick it looked like a blade that had elected to be a fish instead. He had carried it by a strap across his brow so that his hands would be free for the oar and for the spear, and he had the particular walk of a man who could go down anything without trusting his knees to stop him at the bottom. He set the boat down with care that made Corin smile despite himself and scratched Bramble without asking permission, because the boat had counted as an introduction. “Kite,” he said, as if his name were a direction. “Shade says we’re to keep anyone who doesn’t belong out of the water, which is very funny given that all this is water pretending to be other things. Also this is for you.” He drew a coil from the hollow under his boat’s seat; it was a braid, three colors of rope twisted into one. It had the look of a thing that had been made in a hurry by someone who knew their hands too well to do it badly. It glinted along one side, and Liora saw that catgut had been spliced with river-reed with a single hair wrapped through, the hair so pale it might have been a light. “We heard someone say you’d need a braid that doesn’t mind being forgotten by the hair that made it. Shade told me to make one and then forgot he had. That’s how I knew I’d done it right.”

Elyse took the braid as if she were accepting a baby who’d been handed to her by a man who had never held one and was trying very hard not to drop it. She weighed it and ran it between her fingers, testing for arrogance. “It will slip when asked and hold when not,” she said, eyes narrowed because praise is a delicate substance and must be applied evenly or it will run. “I don’t like it. That may be why it’s good.”

The camps around them had already learned the new rhythm of the day. At first the green had been a novelty that made people talk too fast; now it was an imposition that made them wash their spoons with intent. The bell-woman had new assistants, boys too young and old women too stubborn, each with a smaller bell that had their own names burned into the handles so that the wind would know them and be polite when told to move. The masons took down a light-ladder and put up a real one in its place where the seam had sulked, because light is very clever until it forgets to be wood, and then it cuts your foot with its pride. The witchers moved their charmed laundry toward the shade because charms keep their temper better when not disappointed by heat. Vesper’s people—those who wore no color but wore all confidence—carried out shrouds of wire that looked like music written down and looped them from post to post as if stringing a harp between two remarks. Liora watched them with a calm she had to construct from spare parts; each post looked like an opinion and the wires looked like the line every argument goes quiet along when both sides have said everything and the truth is still elsewhere.

They went to choose their place. It was not where Vesper had pointed, not exactly, because Liora had an animal’s dislike of being placed, even by someone who meant well in her own deviant fashion. She took them three lengths to the west, where the blue stone rose into a sort of shoulder and then dipped, making a little cupped space with a view of the column through a lace of cables, and if you sat with your back to the rock you could see both the white shelf with its painted pigeons and the door where those carried by their own élan stumbled and had to be turned gently. It felt like the spot on a hillside where a sheep looks out and decides which foolish lamb will need herding. Corin approved it at once because there were seams any honest wall would want to admit to if coaxed, and that meant he could talk to the stone without being impertinent. Elyse liked the angles because they made it easy to throw anything unwelcome downhill until it reconsidered its choices. Tern liked that there was a line of sight to the thread of the river out past the lower scree; he had a whistler’s obsession with witnessing exit routes even when there was no chance of taking them. Bramble liked it because two pigeons were not painted but real, and had come to argue with their likenesses so loudly that the bell-woman had threatened to ring them without malice.

They staked their claim not with flags, which would have been vulgar, but with actions that look like ordinary accidents. Corin sat and made a circle of stones and persuaded them to stay put despite their natural inclination to roll away in the exact hour a foot needed them. Elyse set the braid in a figure-eight between two rock-lips so that anyone coming in quick would trip on their certainty and not on the rope. Tern laid his oar along the ground and spoke to it, and though it was a piece of wood made for water and not for earth, it consented to listen, because there is no river like the air when it moves in ranks. Liora knelt in the dust and drew with the foreshaft of a reed. Her hand made the gesture the willow had taught her—hello and sit married together—and she wrote a long line that came back to itself and did not tie a knot. A man from Vesper’s side came and stood very near and watched and made a mark on a slate as if she were a creature in a tank. She looked up and held his gaze until his hand did something embarrassing with the chalk and then she smiled in the polite manner people reserve for those watching a dog swim who have never yet gotten their shoes wet. He went away with the expression of someone who would return hand in hand with an explanation later and stand exactly where he had stood before until she gave him a word he could put on a shelf in his head and dust each week.

It would have been better if the count had been shy. It would have been better if it had curled, refused to make an appearance in daylight like a drunk who knows the sun shows every lousy choice. It was instead upright and prompt and went down to five a little after the noon-bell, while men were drinking broth and women were scolding children for trying to lick the sugar-air in secret behind the white shelf’s post. Tern’s tin took on the ugly glamour of a mirror and everyone wanted to look and then not look and then look again. When he cupped it, he did so with both palms, and Liora found herself knuckling her mouth to keep from telling him to put it down because you never tell a man holding a thing that has chosen to be terrible to let go or he will think himself the only one allowed. The mark smeared, the hole showed, and the mountain raised its shoulders as if a story had just gotten good in the middle of something else.

The change touched the river first. It did not run backwards this time; it changed its mind about being a line. It lifted in three places like a boy’s hair in a wind, and at those three places it made a sound between a laugh and a cough and then it lay back down with a shudder that made the fish jump without having meant to. A woman carrying a basket of small birds on her head—an absurd thing to carry on a mountain unless you think the mountain will be hungry—set the basket down in alarm and two of the birds leapt out and turned in the air as if they’d been taught a new language and had to say hello at once. Children cried because any time the world performs, children cry with proprietary outrage. The bell rang. Elyse rang her own bell—a piece of brass she had bought from a tinker who’d sworn it had never been a cowbell in its life and had always been meant for better things—and the tone folded under the Spire’s note with a domestic firmness that reminded everyone within hearing of kitchens where harsh words are not spoken because they would fall into dough and make it tough.

Vesper appeared where people can appear if their feet know the floor. She had ink on her fingertips and something in her hair that might have been crystal powder or might have been flour if she had been very strange and had decided to bake under a column that wanted to undo all ingredients. She did not look at Liora directly, which was to her credit, and she did not look away, which was to it also. “You feel it,” she said to the air between them because speaking to the precise place where a person stands is a power like stepping on their shadow and must be used rarely or you will crush those who would otherwise stand for you. “The pattern is not mine. I am not the hand. I am the tool in the hand. The old ones set it here as you set a key on a nail by the door. The planet has been trying to unlock it for years. It is patient. It is patient in the way of rot. It simply waits for the floorboard.”

“Tools choose,” Liora said, and the willow hummed in agreement because wood knows the difference between a good hand and fools. “You set the Resonatory ringing. You built rooms that make people taller or make them fall. You put ladders of light up where stone used to be. Stone is a poor conversationalist and you have given it language. It is still your mouth speaking.”

“And what would you have me say, Princess of a lake that wishes to be a wall,” Vesper asked, and now she looked full at Liora as if it would do neither of them good to pretend that this was not between them and that the mountain and the sky and the little green children were not merely audience. “Shall I speak the old apology. We did not know. We could not have foreseen. The consequences were unexpected. Spare me. Consequences are always the first thing to arrive and the last to be invited in. Come see the tuner again when the hour turns. We have nearly taught it a note that will let a seam weeps with grace rather than explode like anger. If you still wish to scold me, do it in front of it. It likes to hear women speak like door-frames.”

Liora did not go to the tuner. She had known children who learned to fold paper into little boats and then, because they were clever, could not resist setting those boats floating in puddles that belonged to other people’s houses. There is never a conversation to be had with a cleverness about not setting it in the water, only about where the puddle is and whether the puddle’s owner will come out and say a word that will make someone cry. She sat with her back to the rock and the willow laid along her thigh and she watched the painted pigeons with their round foolish eyes and thought of the woman with the braid telling her to leave a hair in the crack so the cliff would not steal too much. She pulled a hair and tied it around her wrist, not to keep herself from falling up, though the old witches would have laughed and told her it would do that too if she asked, but to remind herself that her hand belonged to her when she put it forward. Elyse did the same because she had always liked Precaution, a goddess of no one’s pantheon who could be called simply by saying her name around a small danger.

Corin had found his work among Vesper’s people whether any of them liked it or not. Two of the light planks had learned to scoff and he did not stand for that sort of goings-on in load-bearing structures. He banged and murmured and stood like a post and waved a boy back from some enthusiasm and lent a woman his pencil and took from her a nail that he put politely in his mouth because he’d no other pocket. The light planks stopped scoffing, which is a good first step in both carpentry and conversation. Kite took a watch without being asked and made himself a silly boy for the children on the white shelf, turning his boat upside down and putting it on his head and calling himself a turtle while the bell-woman frowned and then failed to hide her smile in her apron. Tern drifted toward any place there was a container. He had a way of looking at jars that made them behave themselves and of untying knots without moving his hands.

It came on them like weather that has sent a letter ahead of itself and then arrives precisely when it promised and still shocks because we never really believe things will happen when they say they will. The air put its teeth together and then unclenched. The tin clicked. The mark that was not a mark let go the shape of five and showed the hole shaped like less of a hand. Men made that sound they make when their finger hammers their thumb. Women made the sound that says here we are, here we are. The ground wanted to go down and up in the same breath and had to choose and resented the choice. Vesper set her palm to the blue stone and spoke in an undertone and the undertone had in it the night that comes over ash plain when all the heat of the day stands up and walks away on little legs.

The first rift opened not in the sky but in a story. A woman who had come because her sister had gone up and never sent a line home stood at the edge of their little chosen place and began to tell what she had told herself was true about her sister’s reason for staying away. Halfway through it, the story tore. It did not become false; it became afraid. The words stuck together like bread dough too wet and she made a helpless motion with her mouth as if trying to spit out a thread. Liora touched the back of the woman’s neck with two fingers and thought of the river-man’s tin and of the willow at the dock and of the way people who have never met can sometimes teach each other not to drown. She said one word that isn’t a word, the one you say when a kettle boils over and it would be tragedy to let the soup go away. The tear mended. The sister came in it—that is, the shape of her came—scratching her nose as if this were all irritating rather than the end of a world. The woman cried in the mean, fierce way of those who have refused to cry for six years and now are obliged. Elyse turned away and cut air with her knife because sometimes if you do not cut something the cry goes into you and lodges like a fishbone and is only taken out by pity when you don’t want it there.

The second rift opened in the rope, singing. It rose out of its posts like a snake tired of being a line. The note climbed in a hurry and the boys with their blue snuff looked suddenly both eager and ashamed. The rope tried to teach the note to a flock of things with wings that were not birds but had taken notes well and meant to be helpful. The wings fluttered wrong and the note went ragged as a cough. Liora did not try hello and sit this time. She walked to the edge and held out her wrist with the hair around it. She did not touch the rope. She held the ordinary up to the extraordinary in the way of women who have placed a loaf on a table where three bad ideas have been arguing and said there. The rope laughed. There is no other word for it. It fell back onto its posts with a thud like a brother thrown onto a bed that belongs to him and remembered that it had been made to keep two things in their proper regard, not to be a bird-school.

By midafternoon everyone’s patience was a little thin as old shirts get thin along the back. Bramble had acquired a troop of followers, the kind of children who attach themselves to animals with a sense for their own dignity and who develop at speed a philosophy of goodness that involves crumbs. He led them around three holes and into two that were not holes at all but places where stepping would remind you who you had been in a different year and that might or might not improve your day. He took pride in each triumph and forgot each failure like a saint who has been told not to keep score. He visited the bell-woman with a pinecone held as if it were a valuable that must be appraised. She dinged the cone with the edge of her bell, merry despite habit, and said unsuitable for purchase and put a ribbon around it so the child who had found it could go home and tell his mother he had acquired goods.

There is a limit to how many times a mountain can ask its bones to be revised before something old in it sits up on its hind legs and has its say. Toward evening when the light went less green and more the color of certain bruises on certain fruits, a fault spoke. Corin felt it before anyone else because he had his hands in the seam in the stone and he had been listening to its grievance like a priest. His mouth shaped an oath that would have been worth writing down in a book for future use and he looked up and said without raising his voice, “The shelf,” and everyone who needed to hear it did. The white shelf where the pigeons had been painted had never been meant to carry any weight larger than its memory of birds. It had been gracious for two days. It had been bullied for one. It had been flattered for three hours. It made up its mind to drop its shoulders.

Liora and Elyse arrived first, which is not to say faster but to say that their steps made the kind of argument the stone preferred. The pigeons—those painted, those real—had enemies among the children and friends among the same, and all of them would be under those condescending birds if the edge let go. The bell-woman had her pole ready and she had her bell raised, but she could not ring and hold at the same time, and her eyes told Liora that she had lived a life of ringing and holding and it had made her simply tired. Tern ran into the breath of everybody’s breath with his oar and set it under the lip of the shelf and put his shoulder under the oar and drew a breath down past his ribs into wherever he kept river in his body. Kite came next with the boat and a curse that had been taught to him by a man with both ears pierced twice. They shoved the boats up against the safest place of the unsafe thing because sometimes you put an impossible object between a falling rock and a little skull and the world says all right then and remembers itself long enough to not be tragedy. Corin shoved stones like old pigs until they nestled. Elyse took the braid and looped it around a stump of something that had once been iron and now thought itself a plant and made a figure-eight so quick her fingers blurred, and then she turned and looked at Liora with all the expectation of someone who knows where her own work ends and has eagerly forgotten where yours begins.

It is a terrible power and a terrible risk to be a person whose trick is reminding. Liora put her palm flat to the pigeons because she could not catch the shelf as it was. She could only catch what it had been. She thought of the painter who had stood there on a day that wasn’t this one and made little dabs with a brush and considered whether pigeons might look better if their necks had too much shine, and she thought of the person before the painter who had cut the ledge, not with grand plans for worship but to have a place to sit and put off a shoe and shake a stone into their hand. She thought of the winter when no one came, because people had had coughs, and the shelf had done what shelves do when no one sees them: experienced itself with small satisfaction at not being a path. She thought of the rock under that rock and the muscle of mountain that had been made before names and that had never been told to behave in a room. She said to it, not in any tongue: you are a thing that holds. She let her breath out very slowly so that the breath could be the rope when ropes lie. Elyse’s braid bit. Tern’s shoulder groaned and did not move. Kite’s boat made a stayed sound that boats make when they do the job of houses and resent it secretly. The shelf jerked and then sat, sulky as a child told to sit behind a line until the game says run. The pigeons looked offended and then, being pigeons, adjusted. The children came down from the sugar with their mouths closed in that specific satisfaction of the rescued annoyed by their own gratitude. The bell-woman put down her bell long enough to press the heel of her hand to Liora’s cheek with a mother’s attention that took the sore spot there between thumb and forefinger and rubbed it as if it belonged to her. “Soup,” she said, because some words are spells.

They went back to their place under the scarp with their whole bodies shaking like metal that has been struck, and Liora did what she can do in such moments: she made a list. She thought it in the order her mother would approve. People saved. Where they will sleep tonight. Knives not put away where they should be. Bells that will need new clappers. Stones to be thanked whether or not anyone else thinks it proper. Dogs to be praised beyond what the occasion merits so that later you can be stern without offense. She spoke the list aloud only to the willow and to the seeds under the dirt near her knee, because seedlings are the oldest audience and never gossip. Bramble put his chin on her ankle and wriggled until his eye was looking straight up her skirt in that unthinking doggish way that ought to have been a scandal and only made her laugh in a little frightened stutter that let something out of her throat she had not known she was holding.

At dusk the tuner sang. There was no other way to think of it. Its note, which had been an engineering, became a voice, and the voice did not belong to any person. It was clean the way a knife is clean when someone else has sharpened it too much. Vesper stood with her back to the room where the column stood. She let the note touch the front of her like rain, and her mouth quirked as if the rain had guessed a secret and there was sport in being found out. The count slid with the unfunny grace of a spoon through stew and became four. The breath went out of a hundred chests at once and back in, and on the exhale the mountain burped, with all the embarrassment of something so old doing something so undignified. Far under them, maybe under the black roots of the Black Spire itself, something in the rock went loose and turned, and the sound it made was like someone’s grandmother clicking her tongue against her teeth at a bad joke told to a child.

In the half-light between then and full night a woman came up the path with a bundle wrapped in a coat. She was thin in the way of people who have eaten all the good things and then given them away, and her mouth had taken to making lines that were not expressions, just evidence of weather. She came straight to Liora because that is the problem with becoming a subject in a story that is being told before it is finished; people know where to find you. She put the bundle on the ground and opened the coat and there was a baby in it who had seen three hours of the changed green and had come to the conclusion it would sleep through it if no one objected. It breathed with authority. It had eyebrows that belonged to its father and a chin that belonged to the stone. “He was born when it went to four,” the woman said, and it was the voice of a person who had not decided yet whether to be proud or angry that her child would have this sort of drama in his pocket for the rest of his life. “Tell me. Will he be all right.”

Liora knelt and put a finger under the baby’s hand because babies are very firm in their opinions about whether your finger is a good place to rehearse holding. He gripped and released and gripped again in a rhythm that had nothing to do with the mountain and everything to do with his body’s small chores. She looked at the woman and let her mouth be the place where truth is allowed to be kind. “He is born,” she said. “That is the kind of all right I can promise. He will make other all rights as he goes. None of them will be as important as the first one, which is the one he has already done. If you would like him to have a name that makes it easier for him to stand when all this is done, pick one with two syllables and a sound in the middle he can bite. Names like that go well with soup.” The woman laughed, because the particular sort of person who laughs at soup-jokes is exactly the sort you need on a mountain that has decided to pretend to be a story, and she wrapped her baby up and went away relieved in the peculiar way of those who have not got any certainty and have chosen to like the shape of the uncertainty they’ve been handed.

The Night-Tears sprouted at moonrise. Elyse whistled under her breath the way you whistle when a horse you do not own comes near enough to decide about. They had put up two leaves apiece as neat as any apprentice’s first attempt at tidy handwriting, and at the heart of each leaf a small bell budded with its mouth tight shut. Liora had not expected it so soon and felt in the sprouting the trick that Vesper loved so much she had built a city out of it: if you do something at the right place and the right minute, everything will grow up immediately and you will feel like a god. She wanted to loathe the satisfaction and could not; she accepted it like a loan she would pay back with interest in times when nothing grew and the mountain sulked, and she put her palm over the little bells and whispered, “Not yet. Not until ringing would be a kindness.”

Sleep was a matter of closing eyes and then being told by every small thing you had met that day that it would like to review its notes with you at length. Liora went under anyway, carrying her fear like a child hip-carried, not because she loved it but because putting it down would only make it cry. The dream came, of course. It came and then hesitated like an actor at the edge of a light and then stepped in because no one had signaled it not to. Vesper was not in it. The lake was. It looked like itself and then, when it breathed, it looked like a chest and then like a mouth and then like nothing but water again, which is the kind of trick that keeps people living beside it forever and calling it their friend despite all the ways it can get you killed. It said nothing. It did not have to. It did what it had done at the dock and under her ear and once when she had been very small and had put both hands to its chill in a season when putting your hands into things was the fashion. It lifted her name and set it down and she felt what she had felt in front of the pigeons. Remembering. It isn’t easy to teach stone to remember because it already remembers everything. It is easier to teach people that we remember incorrectly and should not let cleverness do our forgetting for us.

She woke when voices ran along the scarp like hares and leapt into their little hollow all at once. Tern had his hand on the spear and Elyse’s fingers found her knife as easily as nails find teeth. Corin sat up and his pencil rolled out of his hair where he had stowed it and Liora caught it before it fell into a crack where she would not be able to retrieve it without crying. Kite peered out from under his boat with the face of a man who has learned that boats are good roofs but poor walls. It was not an attack. It was a rumor, the kind that wears boots. A boy panting and a woman pale and a man who had tried to keep his hands clean and failed three times. “It’s gone to three,” the boy gasped, his chest doing all sorts of nonsense. “It took two in one and we don’t think we like that and the tuner is laughing and also there’s a storm from the ground up which is wrong.” He bent double, hands on his knees, and made a sound suspiciously like the bell-woman’s bell, which is what happens when you live under a bell for a day and then try to have a body.

The tin was colder than it had been; whether it meant anything or was simply skin making stories of its own, Tern did not speculate aloud, which is one of the ways he is better than most men. He held it under the moon and everyone saw the hole that had been four become a hole that was not and the terrible surety of three take its place. The green did not get greener; it tired. It limped to the edges of things and waited there like a candle that knows its wick is a poor one but has hopes for the tallow. The air crawled like skin on a winter-night after a rumor of lice. Liora stood and looked toward the blue room because she knew that is where every story would be pinned when it ended, and then she chose not to go there. She went to the white shelf, because that is where the children had gone to lick sugar before and would again, and she went because if Vesper wanted her in one place she would be more useful a breath away, uncounted.

On the way she met the witcher of the bees, walking as if she had always known where this path would be when she was old. The bees were with her—not all, just the ones who had names that could be spoken without dignity’s loss—and they wrote rude words above her head in gold for the green to swear by. The witcher had a knife on her hip and a smear of something moss-colored across her mouth like a kiss from a hill. “It begins,” she said, not in a grand voice or a frightened one. “The rooms that teach the sky to sing will have their say and then they will subside, because everything does. This is not about gods. This is about habit, and your Vesper has given the world an idea so strong it will go until it is exhausted, and then it will fail. We will live in the failure. It will be ugly like a house built by a man who has never owned a square. Give me your hand.”

Liora gave her hand because it would have been foolish not to and because she trusted her. The witcher put something on Liora’s palm that looked like a button and felt like a fingertip pressed to her skin. It had warmth and a pulse, and when she closed her hand around it, it melted with a sordid intimacy that would have embarrassed her if it had not been a charm. “That’s a piece of the old song as it was badly sung by a man very much in love,” the witcher said. “It will remind you in a moment you cannot remember. Don’t be precious about it. It is made of mistakes. Those are the best bits of anything.” She looked at the willow and then at Liora and then at Elyse and Tern and Corin and Kite and Bramble, and she made that little bend of her head that made you feel like a person and not a child, and then she went on toward the place where all the people stand when they are asked to prove that they meant to mean well.

They set their feet. You cannot really say more than that about what anyone did after that, because there are hours in a story when everything becomes either one motion or a thousand, and in either case you will only insult it if you narrate. The white shelf held because it had been asked and praised and scolded all at once and did not know how to disobey all three at once. The bell-woman lost her voice and her daughters took her bell and rang not quite on the beat, which is best for waking the entranced because perfection reinforces dreams. The rope stopped being a soprano and became a baritone, and every man who had thought himself immune to the charm of music remembered his mother’s hand on the back of his head, and how her ring had dug in if he tried to duck. The tuner laughed exactly once and then felt shy about it and made its note fatter, which is something fat notes sometimes do before they decide to roll over everything. Vesper’s eyes shone with the happiness of someone whose experiment has proceeded like a parade, and then her eyes went sober because she too had learned something and it wasn’t the thing she had meant to.

At two, the ground did a peculiar thing and carried everything two inches to the left and then put it back very gently as if to insult no one. A woman dropped a pot and it broke in two pieces so neat Corin put them back together and the seam kissed itself like an old scandal. A boy looked up and said in the voice of those who will grow up to write down lies that will save lives, “I think it is trying not to hurt us,” and his father said nothing because he had seen cows run in one direction when lightning strikes and the look in their eyes had not been kindness but haste. At two, Liora felt the taste of metal in the back of her mouth and bit the charm the witcher had given her and it tasted of a room with a table where a man had said sorry in a way that made apology a thing with weight and warmth, and she felt the stone under her feet approve that taste, because stone is not sentimental but it respects warmth.

At one, Vesper came and stood where the pigeons could see her. She had never cared for pigeons and did not begin now. She did not speak. She lifted both hands and then, because she was too honest with herself to be theatrical at the very instant when any gesture might be the one that would be made famous on napkins, she let them down again and put them on the blue stone as if to feel any last tremor before the place where counts become not-counts and numbers go to wherever numbers go when dismissed. Elyse took Liora’s wrist and Liora took hers and Corin put his hand over both like it was a block he had set. Tern set his oar. Kite set his boat with an intimacy that made it one more thing that would be offended if it failed. Bramble stood up with his paws planted too wide because he had never enjoyed the concept of balance and had only ever excelled at presence.

The count shed its last mark like a snake sliding out of its skin. The tin cooled to nothing and then warmed, which is a trick metals have when they intend to lie to you. A wind rose not from the ground or the sky but sideways, as if a door had opened in a wall no one had thought was a door, and it smelled of rain on dirt that had not known rain for a while, and also of old oil on old hinges, and also of the inside of a sleeve where a woman had kept a letter for a day and then burned it because she had decided she liked being right more than she liked being happy. The column did not blaze; it inhaled. Everyone felt themselves be taken into a breath that was not theirs and then set back down as if the world had done a trial lift and found them heavier than they looked. The tuner sang a note no throat can hold and the rope laid itself against its posts like a hound forbidden to jump. Somewhere a child laughed, because children will laugh at weddings and funerals, which is what we have to forgive them and love them for, and Vesper closed her eyes as if to keep something from spilling out of her. Liora did not close hers. There is a sort of seeing that is only possible in ugliness, and she meant to do it.

The end, which had been rehearsing, did not occur. This is the mercy of the world. The end did not occur, but a different thing did. The Spire did not unmake the knot; it let it slip. It did not untie anything; it let it loosen. The mountains around them did not kneel; they shifted and put their weight differently on their feet. The river did not turn and run at the sky; it found a new path down and took it laughing in the dour way of rivers that have been reminded they prefer jokes to pronouncements. The green did not become black; it became a color that had never been named because there had never been a reason. It was like the inside of a leaf held to a lamp. It was like copper washed too thin. It was like old glass at the bottom of an old sea. People began to breathe wrong and then right again because that is what you do when something enormous spares you.

Vesper opened her eyes and looked at Liora and the look said three whole books in a sentence. Liora looked back and said four in five words without speaking any of them. The bell-woman sat down because she had rung too much and her daughters stood over her, one with a hand on her hair and one with a hand on her heart. Corin put his forehead to the stone and did not apologize because he had done his part better than that. Elyse exhaled the way women do when they have had to hold too many breaths while men finished being clever. Tern kissed the tin disc because it was the nearest piece of luck and then spit on it to take away any curse of pride. Kite put his boat on his head again because it had worked once and might again if the gods were of a practical sort, and surely some of them were. Bramble sneezed and looked startled and then pleased, which is one of the most complete reports anyone gives on any event.

The mountain, which had prepared, prepared again, because preparing is the way old things move toward change without giving away the dignity of their slowness. In the silence that came after the not-ending, Liora heard the lake. It is foolish to claim that; she knew it as she thought it. But the drum under the water that had been beating all week beat once now, here, under stone and under light, and she knew what she had always half known and refused to say because it would have meant she must act. The rooms were not rooms. The column was not a column. The count was not a count. They were arrangements. They were a choreographed remembering. Someone had taught Alderra to be a planet by singing it a song and then never sung the rest. Vesper had given it a chorus and it had hummed along as any good student will when put before a tune. It was not an ending. It was a modulation. Vesper’s face, in that moment, held grief for every ending she had promised herself to love and the small surprise of relief that she might not be headmistress at the death of the world after all.

It is a great inconvenience when the apocalypse refuses to keep to schedule. Men must put their shovels down and pick them up again, and women must take off the kettle and put it back on, and everyone must learn a new way to be large or be small depending. The Spire had not undone; it had shifted the music, and in the new key many old songs could be sung and some could not and someone would have to write the ones that should. Liora sat with her back to the rock, the willow humming like a contented cat, and she thought with an irritation that tasted like gratitude that there would be time, now, for all the wrong arguments and some of the right ones. Vesper seemed to feel the same and disliked it and welcomed it and looked at Liora as if to say, Now we will find out whether you prefer governance to theater.

Night came honest and with a few stars that had not been present lately. They looked washed, like children’s faces after the first crying. People ate what they had and then what their neighbors had and then scolded each other for not having saved. Liora wrote on a scrap and put it into a reed and pressed it into a little runnel that had more confidence today than yesterday and said, “Take it home. Do not show it to the fishmonger. He will say heroish isn’t a word in front of my mother and I will have to be dignified and I do not prefer it.” She told Tamsin the count had gone into a new shape and that she would not come down at once because a woman who has stood for an ending is required to stand for the not-ending too or else it looks like her courage belonged to someone else. She signed it in the way she had always signed such things for her mother: with a small drawing of Bramble’s ear, which was the only thing she had ever been able to draw with any confidence.

Vesper came at last, late when late had become simply a number. She sat—not on the stone, which she distrusted now because it had surprised her, but on the edge of Liora’s circle of ordinary. There was dirt on her cheek again and a thread caught between two fingers because she had learned to embroider something in a spare hour once and had taken her skill with her into this foolishness. “Your no,” she said without preamble because manner is an affectation and not a virtue, “did not stop me. It did not even slow me. It shaped me. I dislike you for that and am grateful. Do you mean to stay long enough to make a nuisance of yourself.”

“I mean to stay long enough to send children to bed when they should be sleeping, and to tell you when your men set a ladder of light where a ladder of wood is required, and to clap when your rooms open without killing anyone,” Liora said, calm despite the way her knees ached and the way her mind wanted to gallop. “I mean to talk to the lake when the mountain grows bored of me and to ask the old bee-woman for honey that remembers. I mean to be uninteresting whenever your work will try to turn me into an anecdote. I mean to watch you not end us, Vesper. I mean to watch you fail to be a hinge and succeed at being an instrument and at the end of it all I will go home and explain to my mother why I invented a new word and tell her she was right about every other thing and that will be hard and that will be good.” She smiled, and this time the smile was not a weapon or a shield. It was a reasonable human happiness at having shouted at weather and not been drowned.

Vesper looked at the willow and at Bramble, who was asleep on his back with his paws curled like the hands of a man blessed by a priest he did not believe in, and at Elyse and Corin and Tern and Kite, who were each pretending to be asleep in the exhaustive way of tired people who will not admit it lest they be asked to get up. She lifted a hand and then put it down and made no grand gesture. “Very well,” she said. “Stand opposite. I will tell my people you are to be indulged when you scold. They will dislike you and then stop. We will make something in the shape of our argument. It will not be pretty.
