It may be right.” She stood and went away into the green that had become a lesser thing, and if she wished that the count had been romantic and catastrophic she did not show it, and if she had never meant the end in the first place, only the music, Liora would not inquire. There would be time for dignity and for insults later. For now, there was a dog to cover with a corner of blanket because he had the constitution of a duke and slept cold, and there was a braid to hang where it would catch, and there were seeds to water with three drops and no more because three is a number seeds like.

Far away, where the reeds whisper when there is news, the lake breathed a light into the black that is the color of all lakes at night. It put its head on its own shore and listened. The heartbeat came slow and sure, not the climbing drum of a countermarch but the deliberate pace of a planet teaching itself, perhaps finally, to keep time to its own idea. In the house with the ledgers, a woman with clever hands and a temper like sober music read a rolled scrap delivered in a trout’s mouth and did not smile until she counted spoon, people, and cows and found them all there, and then she smiled in a way that organized the room and made the lamps steadier. In the market with its twine-tied boys, a child told another that he had seen the lake stand up and sit and this time the other believed him because some lies are only true a week later. The reeds knocked their hollow bones and were almost content to be merely reeds rather than a choir for a princess who had gone north. The night wrapped itself around the mountain with the care that old shawls provide to old shoulders. Somewhere a hawk complained about tardiness and turned into itself, and Liora slept as well as anyone does amid the invention of a new kind of day.

Morning pretended it had always meant to be quiet here, and the mountain indulged it with the sort of courtesy old things extend to young moods. Men woke with backs that had learned new verbs and decided not to complain until after bread. Women shook blankets and found the green had left dust on the wool as if it had been obliged to sign its name. The camp had acquired habits overnight; ropes that had sung set their throats and only cleared them when the wind forgot its place, and the bell-woman’s daughters rang on the half-breath, which turned out to be the right time for bringing people back from the edge without making them feel laughed at. The white shelf, sulky but resigned, accepted pigeons, painted and otherwise, and a boy wrote his initials in the dust and then wiped them away because some vanity deserves to be brief. Liora woke feeling as if the inside of her bones had been scrubbed with snow, which is a respectable form of tiredness, and when she sat up the willow had left a pale line on her forearm like a note written by a friend who had not wanted to wake her.

Communiques arrived the way they do when a place has become a crossroads without permission. A trout reversed his arrogance long enough to allow a reed across his back, and Shade’s hand was in the loop at the top—broad, tidy script that made every letter stand like a soldier. He had tied a knot the river would remember and the knot had reached Liora’s fingers without a scratch. Shade said he had heard the count pretend to be finished and fail, and that he approved of the mountain’s refusal to indulge theater, and that he was sending Kite’s cousin not because he did not trust Kite but because there was a woman on the south bank who had begun to sell ladles with the green set into the handles and it made him feel misunderstood in a way that needed hitting with oars. He added, almost as an afterthought, that Tamsin had sent a line but he was not opening it because he liked his ears where they were and would prefer to keep them. Liora laughed aloud and then did not, because her throat had not yet forgiven last night’s alarms.

Tamsin’s letter came in a reed that had been polished by thumb and patience until it thought itself a flute. The paper inside had the smell of the ledger room—ink and lemon and an argument about whether candles should be allowed within arm’s reach of a window. Liora sat with Elyse and Corin and Tern and Kite with their shoulders set like a bench, and she read in a voice that had not yet re-learned frivolity. Tamsin wrote that she would accept any outcome that did not involve losing her daughter or the lake’s temper, and that she preferred the sort of bravery that sets tables and makes sure someone has tied the goats, and that if Vesper tried to set the count to her name then Liora was to say aloud the phrase you are quite boring at your worst and then remain silent for two full breaths, because silence is the one thing people who admire themselves cannot resist filling. She wrote, in smaller script that tightened like a knot, that she loved Liora in a way that had ruined her for comfort and that she thought the new word heroish might be forgiven if used only to describe dogs at dinners.

They learned the life of modules and alterations the way you learn a friend’s domestic habits without intending to. After the green softened, the ropes took to humming when anyone tried to put a lie through them; a man told his companion he would be back by sundown even though he had no intention of being less than three days and the rope above his head made a noise like a tired aunt. Night-Tears budded and held their mouths shut with decorum until the first liar came to sit on Liora’s stone and boast. He wore the green like a scarf and had the satisfied slump of men who have tried to die elegantly and been thwarted; he said he had gone up for children, and two buds rang so purely that even the pigeons put their heads under their wings in embarrassment. The man went red to his collar and then, to his credit, said, “All right. I went up because I have never been tall enough in any room and I wished to be taller," and one of the buds let out a small chiming that was not approval so much as a mitigation. Elyse looked at the little bells with the fond grimness of a woman who keeps a drawer of labels for jars and does not usually need them; she pressed a fingertip to one bud and it settled as if it had been patted.

Vesper sent a messenger with hair cropped too short to tie back and a mouth that had been taught to keep statements where they belong. The message said, politely, that another room would be opened by noon, and that those who had opinions about rooms were welcome to hold them close and then come and lay them out in an orderly fashion afterward. The new room, she had written with that airy cruelty Liora could not help admiring, was called the Archive of Weathered Names, which had once been a library and then been a cupboard and then a rumor and had lately been a wall. “It will allow,” the messenger read without inflection, “adjustments to the burden of seasons on places that have been badly served by habit. We will try it on the Fell-Flats by dusk. Bring your objections and your bells.” The messenger held the last line in the air just long enough to be scolded by her own ears and then went away before anyone could decide to object at her personally.

Corin, who had found in Vesper’s people a tribe with whom to argue about weight and shame, went to look at the gutters cut for the Archive with that look of his that makes stone confide. He came back carrying dust on his shoulders like a new coat and told Liora that the room was more cupboard than library, and that it did not love names so much as it loved cataloguing what is left after names have been worn thin. “It will be useful until it remembers being hurt,” he said, and made tea with the seriousness he reserved for nails set in the wrong grain. Elyse sat on her heels and shaved down the braid Shade had sent until its pride was less obvious to the eye, and while she worked she told a story about the last time a woman tried to adjust seasons with her hands and forgot she would have to hold the new ones steady when they arrived. “People like beginnings,” she said, tugging a knot into obedience. “Nobody likes standing in the doorway three years later and shooing out the drafts.”

The witcher came with her bees at midmorning and set a jar on their stone with the solemnity of treaties. The honey inside had become the precise color of the green when it lay down into the valley and pretended it had not been elsewhere; when you tilted the jar, light moved through it like a fish remembering its river. “For when you need to tell the truth and want it to keep its hair combed,” she said, and then, because she was unkind in exactly the right way, she looked over Liora’s shoulder at the Archive and added, “And for when Vesper tries to prettify a thing and forgets to admit she has, which is not the same as lying but is hungry for the same food.” She drew a line with her boot on the ground and bees followed and went into the line one at a time, humming in numbers that pinned the ears. “You will appear in their story,” she told Liora without any comfort in it. “Be someone they must speak carefully about or they will say ridiculous things just to hear themselves.”

Shade himself arrived before noon with reeds in his hair because he had promised and because he liked to keep to the letter when the spirit tried to get clever with him. He had one hand on the shoulder of a woman who had been a river-knight longer than any of the boys had been alive, and in the other hand a bundle of oars so clean you could have used them to teach a child the shape of a straight line. He greeted Kite with mockery that made a home of his mouth and then embraced Tern like a man who is thankful in quantities small enough to be spoken but large enough to be seen. “I hear heroes,” he said to Liora so quietly it was nearly a courtesy, “and I prefer bread. If I am required to lift anything that is not a boat I will protest. I have brought with me four men who will not listen to women unless you put a fish in your hair, which is a failing of their childhood, not their souls, and three women who cannot stand Vesper in person and adore her at a distance, which makes them very useful in a crisis. Where would you like me to lay the oars so that they will be in the way of anyone who comes running cleverly.”

Liora pointed him toward the path that had acquired a habit of becoming a ribbon when no one watched it, and he arranged the oars across it with the artistry of a patient man making mischief. Tamsin would have liked him, Liora thought; they were of a species that had learned to prefer the friction of decency to the smoothness of adoration. “You’re late,” the hawk announced from a post where no hawk had perched while anyone was looking, and then, seeing that nobody would be impressed by its tardy wit, turned itself into a puff of memory and left Corin coated in a fine layer of inconvenience. “I dislike that bird,” Elyse said, sneezing delicately and pinning her braid to the rock, and Shade grinned as if the hawk had been sent precisely to test whether they were taking themselves too seriously.

The Archive did not open so much as consent to have its lids removed. It smelled like rain and laundry and old paper that has tired of telling its story. Inside, names lay in drawers like folded shirts that had not been worn since the family got rich and then poor again. Vesper’s people moved among the cabinets with the attentiveness of pickpockets and the ethics of librarians; they pulled out trays and did not sniff and did not propose improvements, and this restraint made Liora inclined to like them in ways that irritated her. Vesper stood with her hands behind her because she could not be trusted with them around an unclaimed instrument. She turned enough toward Liora that Liora felt included and not enough that she felt claimed, and Liora appreciated the courtesy as one appreciates a door held open on a day when you intend to argue past it.

“We will try the Fell-Flats,” Vesper said, tone uninflected and therefore dangerous. “Three hamlets sit in the wind’s lashed lip, and this year their grain will try to set in cold and fail. We will edge the seasons and see if the grain will accept a different invitation.” She looked at Corin, because he had spoken against her seam the day before and she had learned the value in being warned by the man who disapproved. “If we are wrong, we will be wrong in a way we can stop. If we are right, I will take down a mountain of medals I have been granted in the last month by men who think we are in a war and have mistaken engineering for victory.”

“Don’t talk like that within earshot of medals,” Elyse said, sliding the braid into a place that would prevent anyone from becoming pleased with themselves and therefore injured. “They tarnish on purpose when they feel unappreciated.” Vesper’s mouth did the not-smile again, small and unguarded enough that Liora had to look away to keep from liking it.

They did not go to the Fell-Flats. It was, Liora argued, one thing to move the burden of a season on a page and another to move it on a woman standing in a field with cramp in both hands. “If you’ve a trick to play,” she said, with that careful politeness Tamsin had advised in her letter, “play it on a place that remembers it was empty. If the Archive is honest, it can edge frost on stone. Then we can count to three. We can make soup. We can do it once more with courage.” Vesper considered the alternative with visible impatience and then, because she had somewhere learned the difference between concession and insult, she nodded and flicked her eyes toward the masons. “Find me a corner that will not break anyone’s heart if it goes wrong,” she said, and three men ran as if she had said their names in the tone of payment.

The corner turned out to be a shelf of basalt that had, in some other life, been a river bed and now was a memory of water and a home to small stubborn plants. The Archive hummed at it as if reminding a child how to sit. A woman ran her hands along a drawer labeled Frost–Unmarried and drew out a ribbon of something white that was not cloth and not light; when she put it to the stone, the stone pretended to be morning in a month it had not meant to see. For a moment it was too much like theater and Liora felt her temper climb as if it had been invited to perform; then the stone sighed in that way of old things finding a position they can maintain without resentment, and the frost settled into a filigree that looked like the veining on certain sweet loaves. Corin crouched, put his knuckle to it, and came up with a touch of ice that did not bite but did not flatter either. “Once you’ve done it, you can do it again,” he said, half warning and half benediction. “That is the problem and the gift.”

They all felt it when the Archive looked at the Fell-Flats as a child looks at the cakes laid out of reach on a high shelf. It wanted to show off. Vesper’s jaw moved, the small muscle that lives along the ear speaking to the parts of the body that do not listen otherwise, and she did not permit it. Liora did not applaud because withholding applause is sometimes the only respect worth offering. She allowed herself the mean little glee of observing Vesper behave like a governor rather than a virtuoso, and hated the glee because it did no one any good.

Disappointment, like mildew, has to be looked for or it finds you first. In the camp at the far edge where the banners loved color more than they loved anything with bones, a group had taken to calling themselves the Lusters, because there are always people ready to make a club out of their weather. They had been saving their stares for the count’s last breath and had been cheated of a tidy apocalypse, and now they were inclined to push the new work until something broke with a satisfying sound. Elyse came back from fetching water with her braids disordered and her expression cleaner than usual by virtue of irritation. “They are clever in the old way,” she reported, a verdict she did not hand out lightly. “They’ve got a girl who can make light sulk and they’ve told her everyone will be grateful when she finally makes an honest mess. If we don’t keep an eye on them they’ll break the tuner and then write poems about it.”

Kite went to sit in their path with his boat on his lap and the air of a man who would be delighted to be told to move and equally delighted to refuse. Shade took up a position near the rope because men who like to untie knots can be relied upon to recognize people tying them for sport. Tern found the bell-woman’s smaller bell and stood with it like a man who could ring if told without having to be asked twice. Liora went the other way because Tamsin had written in smaller script, do not stand always where you are needed or they will mistake you for furniture. She went to the place where the Night-Tears had put up their second leaves and she whispered to them about patience and then laughed at herself for the kind of person who whispers to bells in seed-form.

It was Corin who found the writing under the Spire. He cared for vents and seams the way some men care for the backs of children’s knees, and when Vesper’s people needed someone to go into a slot cut by the old ones with very little regard for human ribs, he was the one who would fit and whose pride would not take offense. He came back hours later with dust in his hair and his wrist scratched where a tool had forgotten its manners, and a look in his eye that Liora had last seen when he had found an old line of mortared stone where a garden shed had claimed to be the eldest thing on a property. “They left jokes,” he said, dazed and delighted. “Scratched in where no one could see them unless they were being insulted by the fit of the place. This one”—and he drew with his finger in the air—“is a little note that says do not stand under this unless you are better than a god at guessing. This one says my sister married an idea and they never had children. This one is a sketch of a pigeon relieving itself on the head of a man wearing a crown and the crown is shaped exactly like this.” He pointed to the lip of the column where it forgot itself and Liora felt the human of the old builders reach up like a weed and take her by the ankle and insist that she remember all grand rooms are built by people who made faces while they worked.

By afternoon the Lusters had tried to make a spectacle and had been given soup instead. Kite had told them a story about the time he and Shade had rowed a mile backwards by mistake because the river had been insulted and then had to pretend they had intended it, and somehow in the telling the urge to break the tuner curdled into a cranky desire to be admired for not breaking it. Elyse passed around a batch of curses she had written in a neat hand and told them they could keep them for domestic use if they promised to insult only tea, not systems. Tern rang the little bell when any sentence grew so elegant it forgot about sense. Liora wrote a line in the dust that said we will not lift what we cannot set down without apology and left it there until someone’s foot removed it because feet are the honest grooms of pride.

Vesper came to Liora not because she wanted to but because leaders speak to the person who has arranged to be an obstacle without being rude. She sat this time as she had before, on the outer rim of Liora’s circle of ordinary, and her eyes did that glitter that belongs to people who have overachieved in their disdain for themselves and are trying to decide whether a compliment might help. “I wanted it,” she said without preface, because the day had knocked pleasantry out of her mouth. “I wanted a clean end, a good story, a beautiful last note, and I have been given this instead, which is work, and scheduling, and the particular fatigue of knowing the better thing will be to get up tomorrow and get up again after that. You can make fun of me now if you like. I deserve it, though I warn you I may enjoy it.”

Liora considered the delights of unkindness and let most of them go because she was, alas, improving with practice. “I will save it for an hour when I am tired and you are arrogant,” she said, which earned her a proper smile and the raising of a shoulder that suggested Vesper had wanted to be forgiven and was angry to find that forgiveness had no glamour. “Tell me why you hate doves,” she added, because small questions won where all the large ones make enemies, and Vesper blinked and then, absurdly, told her.

Her father had bred them as a hobby, it seemed, and had given them all names that could be whistled and then had forgotten them and whistled names at random. Half the birds had starved because they were waiting to be called to supper by a song their throats did not recognize, and Vesper had taken that into her bones as one takes into one’s throat a slice of an orange eaten at the exact wrong hour. “I dislike creatures that require a performance to eat,” she said, harsh and precise with the old grievance, and Liora recognized the ragged place where a childhood sometimes puts its teeth and felt distaste at her own complicity in admiring Vesper’s wound. “I will not be a dove,” Vesper said, low, and then the mountain gave a little shrug like a man settling his jacket and the Archive rustled its drawers as if to say there are worse things to be than named and fed.

The hawk, having failed to properly land on Corin’s head earlier, found a new way to insist on its presence: it spoke from the side of a rock where any other bird would have chosen to be quiet. “You will be late to everything you love if you make yourself stay here,” it told Liora with the shamelessness of a creature that has never kept a ledger. “You will be early to your own death if you go everywhere anyone asks you to go. Choose the rudeness you prefer.” Elyse threw her a look that said do not dignify a hawk, and Liora laughed because the advice was useful and because she was becoming more and more the sort of person who used laughter to keep from setting anything on fire.

Late, at the hour when even children who are fascinated by the idea of standing awake under a painted pigeon become heavy as bread in arms, the rope’s song changed and then corrected itself, and six people looked up at once with the same expression: the old one, the witcher, two masons, Liora, and Vesper. It was not an alarm; it was an inclusion. The rope had learned a second part to the tuner’s line and was suggesting a harmony. Vesper looked almost frightened, which is an interesting expression on a face that prefers to be the person frightening others. “It will do this now,” she said, quietly to herself and not quietly enough that Liora did not hear. “The work will go on where it is not pointed. The rooms will learn to talk to one another when I am not in the room. How unbearable, to have made something willing to proceed without my applause.”

“How bearable,” Liora said, thinking of Tamsin in her room with soft lamps and the meticulous comfort of put-away spoons, and thinking of men with oars who measured the world by their arms and did not try to tell the river what it was, and thinking of Bramble, who had at last found the exact place between Elyse and Corin where his heat kept both their ankles warm and had fallen into sleep as sincere as any vow. “To know you are no longer the hinge. To be something useful like a shelf instead.” Vesper made a terrible face and then agreed with the part of herself that had learned, at last, that the better insult is the one you keep.

That night the Night-Tears opened their mouths and did not ring because they had learned taste in their hours closed. They showed their pale throats to the green—no longer the insistence of a plan but the lament of a habit—and then filled with dew and held it like pearls. Liora touched one with the back of her finger and thought of Tamsin’s letter and wrote one back, not with reed and trout but with the ordinary vigor of a pen on paper and the knowledge that rivers would not mind being denied a small errand. She said that she had stood at the place where endings are supposed to occur and had been offered instead the very long work of mending a world that had been taught to think it could be better after it broke, and that she had said yes to the mending because there are only two kinds of people in such stories and she had decided to be the kind named afterward for braids or for sensible shoes rather than for plummets or for glory. She wrote that she would come home as long as she could, as often as she could, as soon as she felt she had left a mark anyone could find their way by in her absence, and that she had invented another word and it was not heroish; it was worksome. She thought her mother might forgive this.

In the hours before dawn, when the mountain tells itself the fables it keeps for grandchildren, something padded past their circle that made Bramble sit up without barking. He lifted his head, sniffed, considered whether to make a fuss, and then, decisively, thumped his tail twice. Liora knew better than to ask him to translate; he had been bred for presence, not for exegesis. In the gray that followed, a woman came into view with a stick in her hand and a baby strapped to her chest and half a loaf under her arm. She had the soft-ankled stride of those who do not know they are being watched by history. “We came up for the end,” she said to no one as if apologizing to a fence. “We will stay for the middle. Does anyone need a stitch put in a sleeve.” She sat without being asked and threaded her needle with floss that had been dyed with onion skins, and Liora found herself stupidly grateful in the way you are when a world has not ended and someone offers to fix shirt cuffs.

When the sun decided to report for duty, the Fell-Flats sent a message by smoke. It did not say gratitude; it said we had frost and did not, and the second part of the sentence had been written by a twelve-year-old with a reckless love for grammar. Vesper saw it and did not pretend indifference, and she did not betray herself by speaking more than the room required. Liora saw her take the news into that place where she carried the story of the doves and the underfed; she saw her rearrange her contempt into usefulness. She stood and stretched and glanced toward the blue room with all the old hunger in her face and then glanced toward the white shelf with a new attention that would not let the sugar-likers stand without a bell. “Come be my argument,” she said to Liora, dry as a piece of toast that would still be the best thing you ate all day. “We will open another room. We will close two. We will tell the rope it is not a choir unless it receives a medal from the bell-woman. We will make a policy about pigeons. We will write it down. We will be contemptibly alive.”

“Worksome,” Liora agreed, because she had found a word and meant to make it pull. She stood into the day with the willow singing a little because it had learned, like the rest of them, that there was more to be done than singing, and that songs might have to be used like tools and tools like prayers and prayers like bells rung not for endings but to get people to come and eat. The hawk’s shadow went by without comment. The rope held its line. The Archive adjusted its drawers hopefully and was told plainly to wait its turn. Bramble trotted ahead to ask the path what sort of foolishness it planned before breakfast, and the path, out of affection, tried to behave. They started for the door with the light planks and did not step on the places that liked to be looked at more than walked upon, and behind them the Night-Tears held their dew and decided to ring later for something that would need ringing more than any of this.
